PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights: Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the Australian Bill of Rights will do nothing to advance the rights of Australians because it is dangerously ambiguous and will cause confusion within the legal system; it endangers our Federal system; and, it is to be administered in an authoritarian manner inconsistent with the present legal rights of all Australians.
Your petitioners therefore pray:
That the Senate rejects the Australian Bill of Rights Bill and all cognate Bills.
And your pet itioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

That the Senate rejects this Bill.

PETITION.TITLE: Cigarette Advertising: Sports Sponsorship
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

We, the undersigned citizens of Australia, being concerned that the association of smoking with sport makes smoking attractive to children and that tobacco companies are exploiting the loophole in the law which forbids the advertising of cigarettes on television, and wishing to remove any chance that tobacco advertising could influence children to take up smoking, respectfully call on the Federal Government to enforce the law which forbids the promotion of cigarettes on television through sports sponsorship.

PETITION.TITLE: Pornography
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That we the undersigned, having great concern because of the spread of moral pollution in our nation call upon the Government to introduce immediate legislation:

1. To provide strict controls over importation, production, sale, hire or mailing of video-cassettes with the open sale of only G, PG, and M rated video-cassettes; and the total prohibition of the sale of R rated video-cassettes so that R rated films can only be viewed in an adult theatre by persons over 18 years. We totally reject the concept of ``X'' rated video-cassettes which would allow the legal sale of hard-core pornographic films for screening in the homes of our nation, which endanger our children.

2. To dramatically improve the Federal Attorney-General's Guidelines for Classification of Video tapes/discs which restrict the importation, production, sale or hire, screening in private homes and mailing by Australia Post so as to include the total prohibition of any pornographic, obscene or blasphemous video cassette, or film containing child pornography, bestiality, sodomy, group sex, violent sex acts with women, such as rape and pack rape, sadism and torture, etc.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House will protect our society, especially women and children from moral pollution and its harmful effects.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
Introduction of any additional capital gains taxes, wealth taxes or death duties is opposed on the grounds that:
they adversely affect the small and medium sized businesses in Australia, destroying incentive and discouraging investment in this important area of the economy;
the Australian economy, and employment in particular, is heavily reliant on growth in small businesses;

any capital gains that might result when owners of small businesses finally sell the business are not ``windfall gains'' but the result of many hard years of work and sacrifice, with very little being taken out of the business by way of salaries so that the maximum amount of money can be ploughed back into the business to create growth and jobs;
Your petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, will protect the rights of private enterprise and reject any inequitable taxes.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Boswell) agreed to:
That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act to amend the Conciliation and Arbitration Act 1904 in relation to industrial matters.
Bill presented by Senator Boswell, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

This Bill seeks to amend the definition of industrial matters in the Conciliation and Arbitration Act by adding the following words-`A reference in this Act to industrial matters does not include a reference to any matter affecting or relating to superannuation or pension schemes or any provision or proposed provision which directly or indirectly provides that an employer shall contribute to a superannuation or pension scheme'.
The Bill will make it totally clear that the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission has no jurisdiction over superannuation and pension schemes.

I have received legal advice that this Bill will in no way prejudice any independent court action which is aimed at clarifying the present right of the Arbitration Commission to rule on superannuation arrangements.
The Bill is not a radical move. It merely reflects the law as it now stands.
The High Court consistently decided that the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission has no power to decide on superannuation and pension issues.
To this effect the High Court has always decided that superannuation and pensions do not fall within the definition of `industrial matters'.

The best example is R. V. Hamilton Knight ex parte Commonwealth Steamships Owners Association (1952), where it was clearly ruled that the provision of pensions and superannuation are not an industrial matter.
This amendment only puts into legislative form what is the law of the land.

It is particularly important that the matter is clarified in the light of the ACTU's current claim before the Arbitration Commission, namely that a productivity increase be paid in the form of superannuation entitlements.
This claim has the full backing of the current Federal Government which agreed to support it last year.
The Government and the ACTU reached agreement without any consultation with employer or industry groups. No regard was given to the individual employers ability to pay.

The concept of a 3% rise in productivity is a fallacy which the Government and the ACTU have been trying hard to sell to the Australian public ever since the deal was struck. However, they have clearly not been able to convince the public.

Spontaneous employer groups are springing up all over the country to try to tell the Government that this productivity increase cannot be paid by them. Farmers and small business in particular will not be able to play their major role of paying the tax burden if more and more costs are imposed on them.
The concept of national productivity is not measurable and there is no way that the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission can measure this validity.
There is also no guarantee that the proposed 3% productivity payment in superannuation entitlements is the maximum figure employers will eventually be forced to pay.
Already we have seen the Secretary of the ACTU, Mr Kelty, publicly threaten that if the unions do not get this deal they will stage industrial action for superannuation claims between 20% and 30%.
We are presently experiencing the disruption caused by a 32% productivity claim in the coal industry.
Furthermore, employers are being told by union leaders that the 3% figure only represents the employees' contribution and that an extra 3% will be demanded as the employers contribution.
This is why this phoney superannuation plan must be stopped before it takes a hold and this Bill supported.
Productivity not only cannot be measured but no other country in the world is using productivity as a measure to get a wage increase.

Of course this productivity claim is a wage increase in disguise just as it was when the BLF introduced its BUS scheme, the forerunner of employer funded, union-controlled schemes. Norm Gallagher said then `Let there be no doubt that this is a wage claim.'
If this 3 per cent productivity arrangement is paid in superannuation entitlements the union movement in Australia will gain unprecedented financial powers.

There is no doubt that unions will attempt to force the implementation of union run industry superannuation schemes, generally at the expense of company operated superannuation schemes. This has already occurred in the building, paint and transport industries.
An examination of the operation of these funds shows clearly why the ACTU is so enthusiastic in its promotion of union-run schemes.
For example, the BUS scheme in the building industry allows the administrators of the fund to deduct $1 in management fees for every $11 a week employers pay for workers superannuation payments.

Figures show that this will give unions in the building industry a minimum of $40 million dollars a year in management fees and trustee fees. There is no doubt that this will be well in excess of any actual administration costs incurred in administrating the funds. No wonder the unions want to run these schemes and will adopt any tactic to achieve it.

Of course on top of the administration fee would be the enormous investment funds available to the ACTU-between $3 and $5 billion-if union run schemes were to spread to more than 50 per cent of the work force as the ACTU envisaged.

Warnings from the Confederation of Australian Industry and other peak business bodies have been given to the Government that if unions are allowed total control of these massive superannuation funds both local and overseas investment confidence in Australia will be shattered.

The Government released guidelines on superannuation funds have failed to allay the fears many people hold in the community over the ramifications of employer-funded, union-controlled superannuation. They have also failed to in any way inhibit the actions of unions who are pursuing union-run superannuation schemes.

The Government has tried to sell the superannuation benefit as a means of providing retirement pensions. A 3 per cent payment taken at age 55 years will not provide an adequate pension-the figure is far too low.
The union run schemes are not a genuine pension scheme. They are merely a deferred payment.
Superannuation for all workers should be encouraged but for the nation's good it must come at a time when it can be afforded.
It should also involve an employee contribution.
Now is not the time to demand that employers have to bear another 3 per cent cost.

I emphasise that the Bill should not be interpreted as meaning opposition to superannuation in the work force, especially where people wish to voluntarily increase their contribution to schemes already operating.
The clear intent of the Government to bypass Parliament over the introduction of union-controlled superannuation deserves the strongest condemnation.

If this Labor Government wishes to introduce superannuation, it should do it openly and in the Parliament of Australia, not by a back door method via the industrial arena where they know enforcement will be by union industrial action: Where it includes a means to increase the funds and financial power of the union and involves methods aimed at compulsory unionism.
This Bill merely states the law as decided by the High Court, that is, that superannuation funds and pensions are not within the jurisdiction of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission.

The changes proposed by the Bill are in no way retrospective in their operation. Legislation can be regarded as retrospective only if it alters rights already in existence not only for the future but also in respect of past transactions.

The present Conciliation and Arbitration Commission hearings are in no way concerned with the determination of existing rights but the creation of new ones. Those rights, once determined, will operate prospectively only.

The point is amply demonstrated in an article by Mr Justice McPherson of the Queensland Supreme Court in the January issue of the Australian Law Journal at page 13. His Honour points out that the functions of the Commission are `analogous, or at least ancillary, to the legislative function'.

There can be no good reason why this Parliament should not, as the proper repository of legislative power, determine that the future rights which may be created by the Commission will not include those sought by the unions in the present superannuation claim.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech reads as follows-

The main purpose of the Wool Industry Amendment Bill is to implement changes to the organisational, funding and administrative arrangements for wool research which are set down in the Wool Industry Act 1972. I will refer to this legislation subsequently as the Act.

Part VI of the Act which provides the legislative authority for present wool research arrangements is to be repealed. The new provisions for wool research and development are to be contained in Part V. In addition, the Bill provides for amendments or repeal of several sections of the Act concerned largely with day to day operational arrangements. It also includes the necessary transitional provisions to give effect to the new research arrangements. I will deal with these miscellaneous amendments and provisions before discussing wool research.

The proposed amendments to sections 8 and 9 provide that persons should not normally serve as members of the Australian Wool Corporation beyond the age of 65 and section 14 provides for the Corporation to meet the travelling expenses of the Government member, as for other members, while engaged on AWC business. The remuneration and allowances of members of Committees established by the Corporation under section 21 of the Act are to be consistent with the relevant provisions of the Remuneration Tribunal Act 1973.

The working capital trust fund established by sections 27 and 28 to receive advances of Government loan funds during the early operation of the reserve price scheme is no longer required. The loan has been repaid and following consultation with the AWC the two sections can be repealed. The proposed amendments to section 427 place a greater responsibility on the relevant parties to reach agreement on the principles of remuneration for expenses incurred in making refunds to wool growers from time to time out of the market support fund. If the Wool Council and organisations representing registered persons are unable to reach agreement, the Minister for Primary Industry may appoint an independent arbitrator to recommend on the principles for subsequent ministerial approval.

The proposed amendments to sub-section 76 (3) of the Act will provide that any proceeds from the sale of wool stores will be used specifically for the benefit of the wool industry. Section 86 was originally incorporated into the Act to preserve the rights of Commonwealth public servants employed by the AWC or its antecedent authorities. It has become redundant following amendments to the Public Service Act 1922. Some minor consequential amendments to sections 28a, 83 and 84a are necessitated by some of the proposed amendments I have outlined.

I will now deal with the main purpose of the Bill, which is to introduce changes to wool research arrangements. This is the third major piece of rural research legislation to be introduced by the Government. It has been preceded by the Australian Meat and Live-stock Research and Development Corporation Act 1985 and the Rural Industries Research Act 1985. The Government's action in establishing a research and development corporation for the meat and livestock industry-that is, the Australian Meat and Livestock Research and Development Corporation; in revamping research arrangements for 12 other rural industries-that is, the rural industries research fund reforms; and the proposed changes to wool research arrangements, illustrates our resolve to establish rural industry research on a fully accountable and cost effective basis. The Labor Government recognises that a high level of such research is vital to the future profitability of the rural sector.

The Wool Research Trust Fund is the largest rural industry research fund, with a 1985-86 Budget of around $25m and reserves of some $44m. It is administered by the AWC under the Wool Industry Act 1972. The Government has decided that the AWC should continue to have responsibility for wool research because of the need for close integration of such research with the research co-ordination, promotion, marketing and industry consultation operations of the AWC and the International Wool Secretariat. The changes proposed by the Government will strengthen and support the successful arrangements which already exist for wool research.
As distinct from the present Act, the Bill provides for a clear statement of objectives in respect of wool research. These objectives are to:
identify more precisely areas of wool research and development that are relevant to the needs of the wool industry;
improve the efficiency and effectiveness of wool research and development;
encourage the more effective use of the resources and skills of the community in general and the scientific community in particular in wool research and development; and
improve accountability for expenditure on wool research and development activities.

It is the Government's strong intention that rural research be focused on areas which increase commercial returns to producers who are responsible for funding half of the research expenditure through statutory levies. In line with this intention the Bill provides a broad definition of research and development to cover all aspects of wool production, processing and marketing.

Responsibility for evaluating the research needs of the wool industry and identifying priority areas for research expenditure will rest with the Wool Research and Development Council which is to be established under the AWC. The Council will have responsibility for developing wool research and development plans and for making recommendations to the AWC concerning the funding of wool research activities. It will also ensure that activities listed in the annual operational plan are carried out in an efficient manner and will report to the AWC on these activities. The Wool Research and Development Council will consist of nine members comprising a chairperson appointed by the Minister for Primary Industry from at least two AWC nominees. In addition there will be four persons selected by the Research Councils' selection committee which was established under the Rural Industries Research Act 1985 and four members appointed by the Minister on the nomination of the AWC. As for other research councils, it is important that wool research be administered by the best available people with a mix of expertise necessary for carrying out the Wool Research and Development Councils' functions.

The Bill provides for the Council to prepare a five- year research and development plan. This plan will be prepared in consultation with the Wool Council of Australia. It will define the principle objectives of the AWC and the Research Council in relation to wool research and development. As well it will outline the strategies which should be pursued to achieve those objectives in the light of an assessment of the economic outlook of the wool industry for the period which the plan covers. The Bill provides for the R and D plan to be submitted to the Minister for Primary Industry through the AWC, for the Minister's agreement. In presenting the plan to the Minister the AWC will be able to make its own written comments. The Minister will consider the plan in relation to whether it is in the interests of the wool industry, whether it is directed towards the objectives for wool research as set out in the Bill and whether it is in accordance with the legislated role and functions of the Wool Research and Development Council. The Bill will allow the Minister to request variations to the plan providing these are made in writing to the AWC and include the Minister's reasons why variations should be made. The Wool Research and Development Council will be required to consider the Minister's request for a variation to the plan, and will be able to make revisions as it considers appropriate.

Provision is made in the Bill for the Wool Research and Development Council to review the plan at least annually, or at any other time, and to consider whether variations are necessary. Where a variation is considered necessary, the Council will make a request in writing to the Minister through the AWC for the Minister's agreement to the variation. The Minister will be able to agree with, reject, or make another variation as the Minister thinks fit. In addition to the five-year plan, the Wool Research and Development Council be required to produce an annual operational plan. This plan will describe the particular R and D activities which the Research Council considers should be funded by the AWC. It will include estimates of the maximum financial contribution which the AWC should make for each of those activities in the year to which the plan relates. The Bill provides for the annual operational plan to be submitted through the AWC to the Minister for the Minister's agreement. In presenting this plan to the Minister the Corporation will be able to make its own written comments on the plan.

The Minister for Primary Industry will approve an annual operational plan submitted in this way unless the Minister believes it to be inconsistent with the five-year R and D plan to which it relates. In the latter case the Minister may request, in writing through the AWC, that the Wool Research and Development Council revise the plan appropriately. As in the case of the R and D plan, provision is made in the Bill for the Council, through the AWC, to request variations to the annual operational plan at any time. The Government considers that the adoption of corporate and annual planning procedures by the Wool Research and Development Council will enhance the AWC's capacity to actively direct R and D activities towards achieving objectives which have been endorsed by the wool industry. It will provide the Corporation with a strong basis for evaluating projects submitted to it for funding against the strategies, priorities and objectives which are identified in the R and D plan. In addition, the planning process will allow the Minister for Primary Industry to focus on the strategic direction and overall performance of wool research without needing to become involved in the approval of individual research activities and their detailed administration.

With regard to accountability for wool research expenditure, the Wool Research and Development Council will be required to prepare an annual report which assesses it achievements against the objectives and activities set out in the R and D and annual operational plans. Provision is made in the Bill for the chairperson of the Wool Research and Development Council to attend a meeting of the Wool Council of Australia to present the annual report and to respond to questions on any aspects of the Research Councils' past or future activities. The Research Councils' annual report will also be included in the AWC's tabled report, thus satisfying the need for direct accountability to the Parliament. In addition to the legislative requirement for the chairperson of the Wool Research and Development Council to consult with the Wool Council of Australia in developing the R and D plan, and subsequently to report and to answer questions regarding its wool R and D activities, the Council will be able to consult with other persons and bodies competent to advise or assist it in any matter relating to its functions. As well, to facilitate an exchange of information about research matters, the chairperson of the Wool Research and Development Council will, along with chairpersons of other industry research councils and the AMLRDC, attend an annual co-ordination meeting to discuss matters of common interest.

I would now like to deal with funding arrangements for wool research and their financial implications. At present moneys for wool research are paid into the wool research trust fund. The financial administration of this fund is conducted by the Department of Primary Industry under delegation from the Minister for Finance. Under the provisions of the Bill the trust fund is to be replaced by a wool research and development fund which will be vested in, and maintained by, the AWC. Moneys raised from the wool industry through Wool Tax Acts and allocated to research expenditure will be paid into the new fund, along with the Commonwealth's matching contributions up to a limit of 0.5 per cent of the gross value of wool production. This is consistent with the matching arrangement for other RIRFs and the AMLRDC.

At present special arrangements exist for the funding from the Wool Research Trust Fund of research carried out by the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation and the Bureau of Agricultural Economics. In particular, CSIRO projects are subject to consultation with the Minister for Science. The Bill does not provide for a continuation of these special arrangements and applications for research grants by CSIRO and BAE will be considered along with all other applications. The Government considers that this is necessary to ensure that all wool research proposals are evaluated in a co-ordinated manner on their merits against objectives and priorities specified in the Wool Research and Development Council's five-year plan. In addition, it will enable the Council to be fully responsible and accountable for its recommendations on the disbursement of research funds and for the administration of these funds. I am confident that this new arrangement will not disturb the harmonious relationship between the AWC and CSIRO nor significantly affect the flow of funds to CSIRO and BAE for wool research.

With regard to the financial implications of the proposed legislation, I do not expect the changes in wool research arrangements to involve additional costs to the Commonwealth. There will in due course be a transfer of the balance of the wool research trust fund to the new wool R and D fund which is to be vested in the AWC.

As I mentioned earlier, the Wool Industry Amendment Bill 1986 represents the third major piece of rural research legislation to be introduced by the Labor Government. It will allow changes to be introduced to wool research arrangements which are consistent with the reform principles underlying research arrangements for other industries. These changes will take place without affecting the special relationship which needs to be maintained between wool research and other promotion and marketing functions of the AWC and the International Wool Secretariat. The Government consulted the AWC and the Wool Council of Australia prior to the development of the wool research proposals. Both bodies support the new arrangements. I commend the Bill to honourable senators.

DEBATE.TITLE: SOCIAL SECURITY (PROPORTIONAL PORTABILITY OF PENSIONS) AMENDMENT BILL 1985

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 19 February, on motion by Senator Gareth Evans:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have the privilege of leading for the Opposition on the Social Security (Proportional Portability of Pensions) Amendment Bill 1985 on behalf of my colleague Senator Peter Baume, who has responsibilities this morning in his capacity as a parliamentary appointment on the Council of the Australian National University. The Opposition is pleased to be able to support this piece of legislation and is grateful that the Government has proceeded with an initiative which was originally undertaken by the Leader of the Opposition, Senator Chaney, when he was Minister for Social Security in the Fraser Administration.

SPEECH.PARA: My involvement and experience with the question of portability of pensions dates back to the period between 1970 and 1972, when I was on the staff of the then Minister for Social Services, the Hon. W. C. Wentworth, when the first series of agreements were entered into to provide for the portability of pensions. As I recall, during that period agreements were entered into with Italy, Greece, Malta, Yugoslavia, and I think Hungary.

The payment of pensions to persons resident outside Australia is already at quite significant levels. As at June 1983 there were some 18,621 beneficiaries of the Australian social security system resident outside Australia and total remittances were some $63,876,000. In 1984 the number of beneficiaries increased significantly to 20,229, with benefits totalling $74,692,000. For the year ended 30 June 1985 there were 22,933 beneficiaries and the revenue remitted overseas was $87,274,000. These people will not in any way be affected by the legislation before the Senate today, as those overseas who are currently in receipt of payments will continue under the existing arrangements. Therefore, this new system applies essentially to those who are currently resident or will be resident in Australia and who satisfy the necessary criteria set down in the Bill for the payment of an overseas pension. In order to qualify for the pension at its maximum rate, it is a requirement that the person concerned shall have been resident in Australia for 25 years within a certain specified period of his or her life.

When the Government originally announced its detailed proposals in this regard on 8 May 1985, it proposed that the qualifying period for the maximum rate of pension should be 35 years. This was because of some criticism throughout the community, in particular the migrant community in Australia. The then Opposition spokesman on immigration and ethnic affairs, Mr Philip Ruddock, indicated that the Opposition favoured the reduction of the period to qualify for the maximum pension from 35 years to 25 years. We announced that at the time of the last general election. I am glad to see that the Government has now, in its rethinking of a number of the aspects of this legislation, decided to adopt the 25-year period.

There are a number of cases which were cited by the Minister in the course of the second reading speech in which people can fail to qualify for payment of pensions because of certain things which appear almost to be anomalies in the existing situation. For instance, people can fail to qualify because they lived in Australia for less than 10 years. This particularly caused difficulties when applied to the aged parents of migrants who wanted to come to Australia to live with their children. Members of another major group who fail to qualify at present are those who have lived and worked in Australia but have returned to their country of origin before they became eligible for an Australian pension. Under the present law they cannot apply for a pension from Australia while they are resident overseas.

A third category arises from the fact that most countries pay pensions only after people have lived and worked in that country for a certain number of years. If a person has not paid contributions from his or her wages for long enough or has not lived in a country long enough, he or she can fail to qualify. Similarly, for some social security systems people need to be citizens of the country. For example, if they have become Australian citizens and have contributed to some other country's social security system, they might lose their entitlement to the other country's pension. Again, under some social security systems, people must be living in a country to claim and receive a pension from that country, and a person can fail to qualify because he or she has moved to another country. Finally, some countries have currency restrictions, so that even if a person is entitled to a payment, he or she may not be able to get it while out of the country. The Minister has estimated that over a million people in Australia and overseas are affected by these problems or will be affected in the future.

The reciprocal arrangements that are touched on by this legislation will be designed to overcome a number of those particular difficulties. That, of course, does not mean that this legislation corrects all the anomalies which may exist within the system. I cite three particular anomalies to which it is worth drawing attention while at the same time repeating that, despite these anomalies, the Opposition is still prepared to give its complete support to this legislation. There has been a degree of concern that advantage and disadvantage will accrue respectively to beneficiaries in countries with lower and higher living standards than those of Australia because beneficit payments will be made in Australian dollar equivalents at the same rate as payment is made in Australia. That, of course, will therefore put recipients of those payments into potentially different categories in terms of the fact that where living standards and costs of living are higher than they are in Australia-one thinks, perhaps, of the United States as an example in fact the relative value of the Australian pension, which, after all, is struck in Australian terms in relation to matters such as cost of living, will not be as advantageous to that particular person. The converse of that, of course, applies in countries where the cost of living and standard of living are lower than in Australia-one thinks of countries in southern Europe-where there will in fact be a relative advantage to those people. It is certainly true that this presents some difficulties. In correspondence between the Minister, Mr Howe, and my colleague in another place Mr Blunt, the shadow Minister for Social Security, the Minister, in a letter to Mr Blunt dated 18 February, said:

A great deal of research work has been done by many countries with extensive social security systems to see if some equitable way can be devised for adjusting payments to match the standard of living of the country in which the pensioner is living. To date it has proved too difficult for any social security system to follow this course.

Indeed, I accept that as entirely correct. I can well accept that the ability to adjust these things relative to other people's standards of living and relative to the cost of living in other countries, which are, of course, very often measured in entirely different ways from the way in which measurement is made in Australia, may cause extreme difficulties. It is therefore only a matter of drawing attention to the fact that among those who are paid pensions overseas, there will be winners and losers, depending on the particular country in which people are resident.

The second anomaly relates to the position of women who qualify for payment of pensions. The new scheme requires that a person's working life is defined under the legislation as being between the age of 16 and retirement age and one has to spend part of the 25-year period, to receive the maximum level of payments, within that range of 16 and retirement age in order to establish the proportion of the pension which is to be paid to the recipient. Because Australia pursues what I think is an increasingly less relevant distinction between the retirement age of men and women, this means that with a retirement age of 60 for most women in the work force, a woman has only 44 years of defined working life within which to qualify for the maximum payment at the end of a 25-year period compared with 49 years for males to qualify for the maximum pension. This could potentially disadvantage elderly women who come to Australia late in life compared to elderly men who at least would have that extra five years to qualify for the pension and the extra five years to be countered on the basis of establishing the proportion of the pension which is to be paid to them.

Madam Acting Deputy President, you will undoubtedly know that recently in New South Wales there has been some litigation under that State's anti-discrimination laws which has led to the courts and the equal opportunity authorities having basically determined that it is no longer within the New South Wales jurisdiction appropriate to require women to retire at an earlier age than men. I suspect that that is a trend--

TALK.START.PARA: —They have the best of both worlds.

—Senator Walters says that they have the best of both worlds. Madam Acting Deputy President, as both you and Senator Walters would know, having the best of both worlds is not uncommon for females in this society. The trend which has been established in New South Wales is one which I suspect is likely to spread throughout the whole of Australia over a period. Again, therefore, there will be slight anomalies because under some State legislation, there will be a redefinition of what constitutes the retirement status of women. I think it will take some time before there is any degree of uniformity in this business. Again, it is a difficult problem that potentially arises. Certainly, there is no easy solution. There is no solution which the Opposition is seeking to put forward at this stage. We merely draw attention to the fact that some potential discrimination arises from the way in which the working life concept is defined in the legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: The final anomaly to which I draw attention is the question of the entitlement of an Australian resident whose resident spouse actually dies overseas. The widows pension is covered by this Bill and is payable to a person who becomes a widow or widower in Australia because the person's spouse has died in this country. That includes a spouse who dies here who is not a permanent resident. A visitor whose spouse dies here is brought within that category. Again, I base that on advice received from the Minister. The question therefore is: What is the status when the spouse actually dies overseas, notwithstanding that both partners were Australian residents? I would assume that the administrative arrangements provided for under this legislation would ensure that that person would not be excluded from the benefit. I would be grateful if the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) in her reply could give some further clarification of that matter. As I said, those are particular issues which arise. In any scheme such as this there will be similar difficulties.

The costs of this scheme are not known. Again, the Opposition accepts that no hard and fast assessment can be made at this stage. However, one of the advantages of the way in which the Government has proceeded with the introduction of this scheme is that each reciprocal agreement with a foreign country will be enacted by way of specific legislation covering the agreement with each country. When the agreement with Italy is finally entered into, which I believe will be fairly soon because negotiations in that matter are well advanced, a specific, separate Bill will come into this place to give legislative authority to the agreement. Because this will be done on a country by country basis, it will allow us at that stage at least to seek to get some indication of the precise cost involved of each of the schemes as they are entered into. So, over a period of years one will be able to build up a more comprehensive profile of the overall cost of this scheme.

The proportion and number of aged migrants coming to Australia is a matter of some significance.The report by the Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs entitled `Aged Migrants to Australia' includes a table on page 14 which indicates, under the heading `Categories of settler arrivals, Australia' that the number of persons arriving in this country under the family migration scheme increased from the 1979-80 level of 18,400 to 34,000 in 1983-84. It is to be assumed that within the family migration category there will be a slight skewing of the figures towards the older age of the spectrum. The report goes on to say:

In general, migrants in the family migration category have certain characteristics which differ from those migrants in other categories. One of these is a substantially older age structure. For example, data available for 1980-81 show that the proportion aged 65 years and over in the family migration category was 17 per cent, compared with 10 per cent for the total intake. . . Available data for 1981-82 show that, of the 21,768 migrants in the family migration category, nearly 3,000 (13 per cent) had reached retirement age, while a further 1,100 (5 per cent) were aged parents. Clearly, the number of aged persons entering Australia as family migrants is not inconsiderable.

A second report by the Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs entitled `Ageing in a Multicultural Society' includes certain tables and predictions. If one looks at the table headed `Population 60 years and over by birthplace, sex and age, Australia 1981', one can see that of the total number of persons aged 60 years and over in Australia-1,140,435-260,099 were born overseas. That is a figure of 22.8 per cent. Projections are given for the year 2001. Those projections show that the grand total of persons aged 60 years and over will be 1,745,139, of whom 595,177, that is 34.1 per cent, will be people who were overseas born. That is a rise from 22.8 per cent to 34.1 per cent over the course of the next 25 years or so. The important thing about that is that, whilst not all overseas born persons will be affected by this legislation, it indicates, as is typical of the whole community, that there is a substantial aging of the Australian population and that there is a continuing rise, with the emphasis upon the family migration program, of the number of older migrants coming to Australia. As a result of that there is a potential increase in the number of people who may be beneficiaries of the scheme which is being proposed in the legislation now before us.

There is one other matter that I think is worth raising and that is the question of how the assets test is to be policed for people who are resident overseas. I can imagine that there would be no more favoured job in the Department of Social Security than to be the overseas assets test assessor for the Greek Islands or whatever it happens to be. A large number of people in that part of the world will be in receipt of a portable pension and will be subject to the requirements of the assets test. I can imagine that Estimates committees will undoubtedly be paying close attention to the expenditure by the Department on overseas inspectors who travel around the Greek Islands, southern Italy, the south of France, Spain and the Pacific Islands-all of the sorts of rather delightful places to which people may choose to retire with some proportional portable pension in hand-to ensure that people are complying with the requirements of the assets test.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you think the fringe benefit will be subject to a fringe benefits tax?

—My colleague Senator Messner is absolutely right. A question now arises as to how the fringe benefits tax is going to be adjusted. We undoubtedly also have a difficulty in terms of what the Government is currently doing about the non-averaging of casual income during a 12-month period. One presumes, in a realistic sense, that Australian missions and embassies overseas are going to have some additional responsibility cast upon them for at least taking some steps relative to the assessment of assets in relation to the payment of pensions.
—What do they do now in England for Australia and New Zealand? They must have some arrangement operating for Australia and New Zealand?

—In response to Senator Haines's intervention, I understand that as far as the United Kingdom was concerned it was simply a matter of forms being supplied to Australia House, Australia House sending those forms to people known to be in receipt of payments in the United Kingdom, those forms being completed and returned, and the adjustment being made. I do not understand that there was any on the ground follow-up as to whether that self-assessment and honesty principle was being properly addressed. Once again I think this is an issue on which we will be grateful to have the Minister's comments when she responds to the debate. It is, however, a difficult situation. One would not want a situation to arise in which persons taking their pension payments overseas were advantaged compared with people who remain in Australia and take a pension. We would not like to see some people thwart the proper operation of the assets test in a way in which people who continue to be resident in Australia are not able to do. As I say, we look forward to the Minister's response as far as that is concerned.

SPEECH.PARA: As I have said, there are some anomalies and some difficulties and it is almost impossible to find any way in which they could easily be overcome. Despite that the Opposition is happy to support this legislation which picks up an initiative of Social Security Minister Chaney and dates back to the days of Social Services Minister Wentworth when the initial agreements were pioneered in the early 1970s. On the basis of those qualifications, and looking forward to the Minister's reply to a couple of matters which I have raised in the debate, the Opposition is more than happy to give its support to this important piece of legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats, like the Liberal Party of Australia and, I presume, the National Party of Australia, have no difficulty at all in supporting the Social Security (Proportional Portability of Pensions) Amendment Bill 1985 which, as far as it goes, is an advance on the current system. I say `as far as it goes' because it does not encompass all the countries which for a number of years have been pressing for a reciprocal pensions agreement with Australia. Those countries include Italy, which has been picked up under this legislation, Greece, Malta, Spain, West Germany and Yugoslavia. Certainly as far as the Greek community is concerned this legislation is not adequate for its needs as it sees them at the moment, so there is still a lot of work to be done in coming to some agreement with countries other than Italy. It is, however, at least a start to the conclusion of discussions that began under the previous Liberal Government when Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle started, to her credit and to that Government's credit, discussions with a number of European countries with regard to extending the portability of pensions agreement to those countries. Up until then, of course, Australia had had arrangements only with the United Kingdom and with New Zealand. The negotiations were continued under Senator Chaney's Ministership and have gone on under the current Government.

SPEECH.PARA: The Social Security (Proportional Portability of Pensions) Amendment Bill 1985 is certainly acceptable as far as it goes. We are concerned that the Government appears not to be evincing any enthusiasm for extending the provisions of this agreement to other countries in terms that they find acceptable. While it is necessary for Australia to come to mutually acceptable terms before it includes a country in legislation such as this, I suspect that perhaps it has not tried, in some areas at least, as hard as it could. Certainly it has got a lot further down the track with the Italians than I was led to believe when I was over there several years ago when some of the elements of what I can only assume was an ambit claim by some people in the Italian community were quite unacceptable to the Australian Government or, indeed, to any government with which a portability arrangement was being made.

This legislation will help Australians living overseas but more importantly, as Senator Puplick has already pointed, it will help people of other origins than Australian with its portability aspect. The pensions, of course, are not automatically portable for people who have been here for less than ten years. There will, under this agreement, be a proportionally based pension portability which will reach 100 per cent only after 25 years of residence. In that regard it certainly is an advantage over the system that currently operates but it will not put these people at any advantage vis-a-vis Australians, for example, so that it is not a scheme that is more generous to somebody from another country than already exists for those who were born here. Although, as Senator Puplick has quite rightly raised, the issue of assets checking is one which is going to have to be much more closely watched now that the scheme has been extended than it ever was when it applied simply to the UK and New Zealand.

Where no negotiated agreement applies, as it currently does not with countries like Greece, the old rules will continue to apply and the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) indicated in his second reading speech that he intends to negotiate separately and to introduce legislation after each consultation process has been successfully completed. However, there is some concern in the community that this is a bit of window dressing, that in fact the wording of the Social Security (Proportional Portability of Pensions) Act as it stands is at variance with the expressed intention of the Minister in his second reading speech. He said in that speech:
I turn now to the changes the Government has made as a result of the consultations with the ethnic communities:

1. Each reciprocal agreement will be introduced by a separate Bill after it is negotiated. It is possible to introduce them by Regulation. However, introducing them by a separate Bill will facilitate more rigorous Parliamentary scrutiny and will provide the ethnic communities and indeed the whole community with an assurance that a particular agreement cannot come into effect until it has been debated by both Houses of Parliament.
2. The basis for reciprocal agreements and the calculation of all pension payments outside Australia will be 25 years rather than 35 years as previously announced.

3. Many people residing in Australia at 8 May 1985 who are close to retirement have a reasonable expectation of taking a full Australian pension overseas. To meet this expectation, the Government has decided to exempt all people residing in Australia at that date from the new rules until 1 January 1996. After that date, only those who go to a country with which Australia has a reciprocal agreement will be affected.

Our concern lies with what appears to be a quite distinct variation between what the Minister said in his second reading speech that he intended to do and what the wording of the Bill before us appears to say will actually happen. The problem is in the wording of clause 4 of the Bill, which relates to proposed new section 83AC. As it stands, the Bill before us means that any future agreement between the Australian Government and a foreign government will have to be in terms of this Bill, not in terms of some other Act. It would appear, at least on the surface, that if some agreement is negotiated with Greece or some other country over portability of pensions, that agreement, whatever else the consultative process takes into account, must be couched in terms applicable under the legislation before us today; that is, only if it is in the same terms as laid out in proposed new section 83AC will the agreement fall into this part of the legislation, and hence anything outside that sort of wording is not going to apply. The problem relates specifically to proposed new sub-section (5) (b) (ii), the relevant part of which reads:
This section does not apply to a person who is in a country with which Australia does not have an agreement that affects the operation of this Act.

I suggest that there is a more appropriate way of phrasing that which would bring it into line with what the Minister said in his second reading speech that he intended to do. I am not doubting for a moment that what the Minister intends is that negotiations and consultations with other ethnic groups in the community will continue and that, one hopes, some time down the track agreements will be reached which may not necessarily be in the same terms as the current agreement reached between the Government and the Italian community. If that is the case, I cannot see how that sort of agreement can be put into effect under the wording of the legislation before us today. It would seem to me much more useful and much more in keeping with what the Minister, Mr Howe, said in his second reading speech that he intended if that part of the clause actually spelt out the two possibilities; that is, that it said:

This section does not apply to a person who is in a country with which Australia does not have an agreement that provides for a pension to be payable to such a person in that country in accordance with this section-
or there were added a paragraph (iii) which said:
Is in a country with which Australia has an agreement that provides for a pension to be payable to such a person in that country in accordance with provisions of this Act other than this section.

It seems to us that that would give the Government the flexibility it clearly indicates that it wants without tying it into simple window-dressing consultations and negotiations which can achieve a successful conclusion only if the legislation ends up in the same terms as those already in the Act with respect to the Italo-Australian agreement.

I confess that we had not expected the legislation to be brought up this morning. I apologise to the Minister and, more importantly, to the poor benighted departmental officials who have to make some sort of Yes Minister decision on this matter. I hope that in the hour between now and the Committee stage of the debate, they will have some time, as indeed will Senator Puplick for the Opposition, to look at this. Certainly our advice has been that if this Bill passes in the form that is before us, the law as it will then stand will not allow agreements to be made which contravene this section of the Act. We will find people tied into this agreement when another, but perhaps not identical, mutually agreeable and acceptable arrangement can be come to unless some change in the wording allows for flexibility, so that everbody's needs and interests can be satisfied.

I repeat that certainly the Australian Democrats fully support the intention of this Government to extend portability of pensions to other countries. We fully support the application under this legislation to extend it partially to those of Italian descent. We regret, as does everybody, that it has taken so long since Senator Guilfoyle instigated the discussions in the first place.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Chaney.
—No, I think the honourable senator will find that it was Senator Guilfoyle who started it, but it was carried on by Senator Chaney.
—It was proposed by him.

—Yes, I said earlier that it was a most appropriate and excellent initiative undertaken by the previous Government and adopted by this Government because if we do not treat these matters in a multi-party way division will be caused in the community. It is sad that it has taken so long to reach agreement, even with Italy. I am afraid that a division will be caused if the Act as I perceive it precludes the Greek or Yugoslav communities from coming to an arrangement with Australia that is different from the one currently being concluded. I certainly hope that with the best intentions on all sides and with the goodwill and everything else that ought to apply in this case some clarification of the problem that I have raised can be brought forward and preferably some change to the wording can be made that will make it absolutely clear that other sorts of agreements can be reached effectively and be put into legislation without being at odds with what is before us today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating the Social Security (Proportional Portability of Pensions) Amendment Bill 1985. As Senator Puplick has already said, the Opposition supports these amendments. As Senator Haines said, they were proposed by Senator Chaney in 1982. It is pleasing to see that the Government, although belatedly, has brought forward this legislation. I will explain how the alterations will take place. At present pensioners are entitled to a pension after living in Australia for 10 years; so when they leave the country the pension is fully portable. When they leave Australia to return, as they often do, to their homeland for the remaining years of their lives, Australia pays their full pensions. It has become a very costly exercise. I shall explain the need for this legislation because the figures are disturbing and are causing concern. They are increasing and increasing quite considerably.

SPEECH.PARA: At June 1983, 18,621 beneficiaries of the Australian social security system were resident outside Australia and remittances totalled something like $63,876,000. In 1984 the number of beneficiaries had increased significantly to 20,229, with benefits totalling $74,692,000. By the end of June 1985 those figures had gone up. There were nearly 23,000 beneficiaries and the figure paid out in benefits was $87,274,000. Is it any wonder that there is a growing concern that something must be done?

It is now proposed that pensions be portable on a proportional basis, in line with the proportion of a pensioner's working life in Australia. Working life is defined as being between the age of 16 and retirement age. That is the basis of the alteration. Only where a pensioner had spent 25 years or more of that working period in Australia will a pension be fully portable. As I have said, the Opposition is in complete agreement with that proposition. The categories of pensioners that are entitled to a portable pension will surprise many people. I think most of us feel that only age pensions are fully portable, but that is not so. The age pension, invalid pension-wives of pensioners are also eligible-widow's pension, carer's pension and the supporting parents benefit are fully portable. So a quite considerable cost to the community is involved when the various beneficiaries are taken into account.

This legislation will not be retrospective. I believe that is a very important point. Full portability will continue for every person residing in Australia at the time of the original Government announcement on 8 May last year. So anyone who was residing in Australia on 8 May last year and who leaves Australia before 1 January 1996 will be eligible for benefits as at present. Some of these people will also be eligible to receive partial benefits from other countries such as the United Kingdom and New Zealand. As has already been stated, we are still negotiating with Italy in this regard.

The problems associated with this Bill have already been mentioned. Mr Blunt, the shadow Minister, referred some of these to the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe). The Minister was good enough to give a reply. I shall explain some of those problems. The first problem relates to the ability to check the eligibility of people in other countries once they have left Australia. There are a tremendous number of countries to which our residents go. I will just read some of them, as Mr Blunt did when he put them in Hansard in the other place. They are Albania, Austria, Czechoslovakia, Denmark, through to Italy and Malta in Europe; the United States of America, Canada and Argentina in the Americas; Hong Kong, India, Israel, Lebanon, Turkey and other parts of Asia; Africa and, of course, New Zealand and Papua New Guinea.

One sees that our residents go to a considerable number of other countries. How do we check eligibility? For instance, can we check the eligibility of someone who has left Australia and is now residing in the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics? It becomes a pretty tricky problem. For instance, what happens with regard to the new assets test in Australia? The Government has been very thorough in checking eligibility under the assets test of our pensioners living here.

TALK.START.PARA: —You haven't got a Minister to answer your points.

—The Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Senator Gietzelt, is here. I would be grateful if the Minister could answer me later as to what happens when someone sells a house, goes to the USSR and takes the money with him. How is that checked? What is the detailed method of checking in those sorts of cases in accordance with the assets test and in line with eligibility criteria for pensioners resident in Australia? I have no idea how that check is made in these countries. What happens in some of the African countries when someone who is eligible for a pension here sells his house, takes the money to Africa and buys something there? How do we check that?

SPEECH.PARA: When Mr Blunt in the other place asked these questions, the answer of the Minister for Social Security was really that it is virtually impossible to check. In some countries, it is easy. He said:
In Europe, the Middle East and most of Africa-
I found this very interesting-
(where 88% of all Australia's payments are made) payments are made through the Department's office in London. The London office reviews entitlements of pensioners in its areas on a regular basis.

I wonder how the Department's office in London reviews the eligibility of people in Africa or the Middle East, in accordance with the assets test. I think that would be a rather difficult exercise, to say the least. I am very concerned that our pensioners living in Australia should not be disadvantaged by the close scrutiny which goes into their private assets under the assets test, as compared with those people who move to the Middle East or Africa. The Minister continued:
In addition, as is necessary from time to time, additional reviews are carried out, for example, in relation to medical incapacity.

I gather those are for invalid pensioners. But how does the Department know whether someone who is claiming and being paid an invalid pension from Australia is not working in the Middle East or in Africa? The difficulties that this presents are insurmountable and I believe that this is an area that must be looked at fairly thoroughly. The Minister said:

In the Americas (accounting for some 5 per cent of payments) payments are made through Australia's post in Washington and in Oceania and some other remote areas (where . . .) payments are made direct by Department of Social Security's State offices. In these areas regular reviews are initiated direct from Australia.

I wonder what he means by regular reviews. The Minister on duty in this chamber has just changed and I hope that the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) who is now here will pick this up. I had asked Senator Gietzelt whether he could explain some of these things. I hope that the officers present will bring the Minister for Education up to date with the questions that I was asking.

There is not only that problem associated with eligibility, but also, as Senator Puplick has already said, problems of equity associated with standards of living. If people took our age pension, invalid pension or whatever to India, for example, I believe that their standard of living would be quite considerable compared with that which would apply in Australia. How is that equitable? How can we make it more equitable? If the same pensioners moved to the United Kingdom, which pensioners probably do in greater numbers, they would find that with the fall in the Australian dollar-our dollar is worth only 48 United Kingdom pence at the moment-they would be at a considerable disadvantage. I wonder what we could possibly do about that.

The Minister for Social Security has said that this is a fundamental problem resulting from different levels of payments being available under the various social security systems throughout the world. He said:
To date it has proved too difficult for any social security system to follow this course . . . My Department is not aware of any country which adjusts its pension payments abroad in this way.

I do not really believe that we should discard the idea on that say-so-that it is all too difficult and that no one else does it, so we should not even look at it. I believe that we could successfully look at this matter and tie payments to the ebb and flow of overseas currencies. That is for the Department to try to work out. As has already been said, we are leaving open negotiations for many other countries in this area. If we are to bring down that figure of $87,274,000 which last year was incurred by Australian taxpayers, this must be done and done pretty soon. If we do not have reciprocal arrangements, as we have with the United Kingdom and New Zealand and presently will have with Italy, the Australian taxpayer will be behind the eight ball.

I was delighted that on this occasion at least the Government saw the need for not interfering with the planning of people, particularly the elderly. It did not make the legislation retrospective; it allowed 11 years for these new regulations to take effect. As the Minister said in his second reading speech:

Many people residing in Australia at 8 May 1985 who are close to retirement have a reasonable expectation of taking a full Australian pension overseas. To meet this expectation, the Government has decided to exempt all people residing in Australia at that date from the new rules until 1 January 1996.

He added that, as previously announced, all existing pensioners, whether in Australia or overseas, would not be affected by the new rules. I was delighted to see the Minister acknowledge the hardship that would face pensioners who had planned for their retirement if there were a sudden change in social security arrangements.

I am only very sorry that he did not acknowledge the same hardship for pensioners at home when he altered the assets test. The same thing applies. If the Minister says in his speech that he understands the situation that many people have a reasonable expectation of taking their pensions overseas and have planned and made their arrangements to that effect, surely that same Minister should have understood the position of pensioners at home in relation to the assets test. Those pensioners had planned and had reasonable expectations, and he should have allowed time for the assets test to come in.

I believe it would have been far more humane to say to the pensioners, those people who are approaching pension age, who have a certain period of their working life left and who have already made their plans on the basis of reasonable expectation, that they could fulfil those expectations. However, I am afraid that that is the way this Government works and there is very little that we as an Opposition can do about it. I am pleased that the Government has brought forward this legislation. As I said, the Opposition will be supporting it. We wish it a speedy passage through the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate has been debating the second reading of the Social Security (Proportional Portability of Pensions) Amendment Bill which is part of a package of measures designed to improve social security assistance to people who move between countries. The package includes provision to enter into reciprocal social security agreement with each of Australia's major migrant source countries and, indeed, any country that is interested in a reciprocal agreement with Australia. I am pleased to note the support of the Opposition for this legislation and I understand that it is is the fruition of work commenced during the time when some honourable senators opposite had the responsibility for social security matters.

SPEECH.PARA: I will respond in general terms to queries raised during the debate but at the outset I must point out that the amendment to be moved by Senator Haines on behalf of the Australian Democrats is not acceptable to us. The technical effect of the proposed amendment moved by Senator Haines would be to undermine the whole part pension portability purpose of the legislation because in fact that would mean that people who were in Australia at the time of the announcement by the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) would be eligible for all time for a full pension no matter where they chose to live. Of course, the whole intent of the legislation, which has been supported by the coalition parties, is quite different from that.

When Senator Haines spoke to her proposed amendment she suggested that the concern of the Democrats was that the Bill in its present form would pre-empt further negotiations for further reciprocal agreements and that perhaps the Government would be tied into a rigid position on account of this legislation and would not be able to negotiate appropriately for future agreements. This is not the case. The position is that an agreement will become part of the Social Security Act by amendment to that Act, thus giving the agreement force of law. That agreement will modify the current provisions of the Act, whatever they may be. In other words, when an agreement is reached with another country there will be a legislative expression of that agreement and the Government will have the capacity to amend the Social Security Act to incorporate the terms of the agreements as they have been reached with the other countries. The agreement Bills will express the override section 83AC and indeed, other provisions of the Act.

I point out that this is the normal way of arranging for the domestic law to be modified by international agreement and is the same, for example, under the Income Tax Assessment Act. There is no question of the terms of future Acts which will give effect to agreements being dictated by the Bill currently before the Senate. The terms of a particular agreement will be concluded by negotiation between the governments during which time Australia's position will be a system of proportional pension based on the terms of this Bill. For example, the agreement with Italy just concluded embodies this approach. For these reasons the Democrats proposed amendment is not necessary, I suggest, against the intent of the Bill and is not accept- able to us. I understand that it will not be supported by the coalition parties either.

Senator Puplick asked for clarification of the position of a married couple who reside in Australia but are temporarily overseas when the husband dies. The position is exactly the same as if the death occurred in Australia. This legislation will enable the woman to qualify for a widow's pension in the same way as she would if her husband's death had occurred within Australia. The fact of her temporary absence from Australia will not affect her entitlements. Of course, she would have to qualify in other respects just as she would if the couple had been in Australia when the death occurred. The temporary absence does not affect the entitlement of the woman to her widow's pension.

The Opposition also sought assurances about the ability of our Government to administer the assets test overseas. Of course, this ability is subject to some difficulties which do not arise in Australia, but the Department's ability to administer the Social Security Act under the proposed regime of proportional portability is no different from what it has been for many years. For example, in the past there was an assets test and an income test, or just an income test alone. In other words, the Department of Social Security has been administering these kinds of tests overseas for very many years; it has the capacity to do that. There are some complications that arise where the recipient lives overseas rather than in Australia, but the Department is confident that it will be able to carry out its responsibilities adequately. I point out that when reciprocal agreements are entered into the Department's ability to administer the Act properly will be enhanced because the agreements will cover administrative co-operation between countries.

Senator Walters asked how often regular pension assessability reviews are carried out. Pension payments are assessed regularly. In fact pensions which are paid overseas are actually assessed more regularly than those paid in Australia. Pension payments overseas are, in most circumstances, reviewed about every 12 months. For example, persons selling their house on leaving Australia would have their pension reviewed each 12 months at least to ascertain what had been done with those assets. It is a very regular pro- cess. I am sure that is a satisfactory response.

Finally, during the debate there was some suggestion by Senator Puplick that the Department of Social Security officers would have wonderful times travelling to France or Italy, preferably in the spring, to carry out these reviews. On the other hand, Senator Walters pointed out that in the case of a pensioner living in the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics there may not be such enthusiasm on the part of departmental officers to carry out that assessment. I do not think the Opposition can have it both ways. I presume that the job of being an assessor for the Department of Social Security, like most jobs in our society including those of senators, has its ups and downs, and there are swings and roundabouts. I commend the legislation to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
