Clause 17 (Mergers and other acquisitions).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Clause 17 deals with section 50 of the Trade Practices Act and proposes a number of amendments to that section, including the now notorious amendment which has been the subject of such intense public scrutiny, even though public interest in this area was very belated. Long before the public concern and the Australian Democrats' concern, as a result of a public debate-following the debate, not initiating it-the Opposition had given very close attention to clause 17 and the proposal to amend section 50 of the Trade Practices Act. We are proposing an amendment which is to be considered now, before dealing with amendments which have resulted from the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd take-over proposal. We are concerned about the new sub-section (2a) which it is proposed be inserted into the present section 50. There is an amendment to section 50 (1) which extends the operation of section 50 to a person other than a corporation, with which the Opposition agrees. To recapitulate, section 50 is the mergers section of the Trade Practices Act. In broad principle section 50 (1) states:

SPEECH.PARA: A corporation shall not acquire, directly or indirectly, any shares in the capital, or assets, of a body corporate if-
(a) as a result of the acquisition, the corporation would be, or likely to be, in a position to control or dominate a market for goods or services . . .

That is the general principle with which section 50 is concerned. Of course, it does deal with a large number of contingencies which may arise in applying that principle. One of those contingencies, in sub-section (2), deals with a corporation that is associated with other corporations. Naturally, it does not look only at what one corporation does, or what power it has. It looks at what a number of corporations that are associated may have.

Proposed new sub-section (2a) provides for a further development of this notion by providing that a body corporate shall be taken to be associated with another body corporate-I am referring only to the major parts of the sub-section-if one of those bodies corporate is, either alone or with another body corporate or other bodies corporate which are related to the dominant body corporate, in a position to exert, whether directly or indirectly, a substantial degree of influence over the activities of the body corporate. The Opposition is concerned about the very broad effect of sub-section (2a), because under the definition of `associated corporation' the body corporate may then exert a substantial degree of influence over the activities of the associated body corporate. We do not see that as being the major question. It is not just a question of whether there is a degree of influence over the body corporate.

The degree of influence is not the important matter from the point of view of the Trade Practices Act. What is important is the ability of the dominant body corporate, if one likes to call it that, to influence the market power of its alleged associated company. So we believe that the very wide definition in the Government's amendment should be limited so that the degree of influence-it may be very substantial influence-which one corporation has over another will apply only if that influence is in a market of in the activities of a market. The amendment which we propose seeks to achieve that purpose. Our amendment seeks to amend clause 17 by inserting the words `in a market' after the word `activities'. Proposed new sub-section (2A), as set out on page 8 of the Bill, states:
. . . in a position to exert, either directly or indirectly, a substantial degree of influence over the activities of the other body corporate.

As I said, we are not really worried about the influence a body corporate may have in a general way. What is relevant from the point of view of the Trade Practices Act is the ability of a body to have a market influence or a dominance. Section 50 is about controlling or dominating a market. Proposed new sub-section (2A) certainly does not do that. I do not think it is intended to have a wider effect. If it is, our amendment will have even greater force in terms of the extended definition of the body corporate which may be able to control or dominate a marker through associated bodies. The merger section will apply only if in fact this degree of influence is able to be exercised in a market. Accordingly, I move:
Page 8, paragraph (e), proposed new sub-section 50 (2A), line 9, after `activities' insert `in a market'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would just like to point out to Senator Durack that we actually ought to be talking about this amendment in terms of `dominating' rather than `control and dominating' since the earlier parts of the amendment are aimed at taking out those words relating to `control'. So we are in fact looking only at `domination' in a market. I think this is another example of what is becoming known in this place as a bauble amendment. I would say to Senator Durack that it is harmless enough. Indeed, I would say the same thing to the Government. I do not think the amendment is necessary because the whole of clause 17 refers to what is happening `in a market'. The words `a market' appear early in clause 17. After all, the clause is made up of a series of integrated parts and, presumably, if `a market' is referred to earlier on `a market' continues to be implicit in the rest of the clause. However, that is just as much an argument for not opposing the inclusion of the words `in a market' at a later stage of the amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: While I am sure that Senator Evans is about to launch into an enthusiastic rebuttal by saying that it is in fact a superfluous amendment and it is only a piece of baubling along in here, might I point out to him that this is not some kind of guerrilla raid on the legislation. Had this sort of debate gone on originally maybe section 50 would not be in the mess that it is currently in and we would not be looking at a market-place situation that is in the state that it is in at the moment with regard to conflict over just exactly what section 50 means when it comes to mergers and takeovers of bodies which dominate a market sector as distinct from a body which already has a monopoly in the market. I can only suggest that maybe if a bit of nit-picking and/or baubling had gone on in the original debate perhaps the wording would have been a little clearer and a little less ambiguous. The original intentions may have been more usefully expressed in the wording of the original section 50. If that had happened we would not now be messing about with section 50 (2C). So, if it is any joy to Senator Durack's life, we will be supporting the addition of the words to clause 17 as set out in his amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are baubles and baubles and this is one, I suppose, that the Government can live with.
—This is a small bauble, Senator.

—It is not even a very shiny one either, it has to be acknowledged, because it really is quite superfluous. The reason for the amendment is somewhat obscure but it seems to be an attempt to confine the areas of an influence of an associated body corporate to influence in a market. If this is intended to remedy a defect-and we do not agree that there is any defect-it should be made clear that activities in the market are relevant, as outlined in an explanatory document. This matter will be made clear by the formal explanation which I now give:

SPEECH.PARA: SUB-SECTION 50 (2A)

There has been some comment that the proposed s.50 (2A) may apply to a situation where two firms could be regarded as associated bodies corporate, notwithstanding that the influence one was able to exert over the other was insufficient to allow the former to make use of the latter's market power.
This would not be so because the influence required for the application of sub-section 50 (2A) must be a `substantial' influence and related to market power.

Sub-section 50 (2A) must be read in light of sub-section 50 (1) and 50 (2). Sub-section 50 (2A) provides a mechanism for determining, through the application of sub-section 50 (2), whether an acquisition has resulted in dominance or increased dominance of a market for the purpose of sub-section 50 (1). Thus any assessment whether one firm is in a position to exercise substantial influence over the activities of another firm, must have regard to the test of market dominance to which s.50 is directed.

In that context, the word `substantial' in sub-section 50 (2A) is intended to signify `large or weighty' or `considerable, solid or big', in the same way as for s.46. (In this respect see also paragraph 40 of the Explanatory Memorandum). To give `substantial' in sub-section 50 (2A) a lesser meaning of merely `real or of substance and not insubstantial or nominal' (see Tillmans Butcheries Pty Ltd v The Australian Meat Industry Employees' Union and Ors (1979) ATPR 40-138 at p. 18, 500) could lead to the result that market power held by one body corporate was not in reality available to an `associated body corporate` within the meaning of sub-section 50 (2A).

Having driven Senator Haines from the chamber with this explanation, I still believe, nonetheless, that it will prove to be of assistance to the courts in interpreting this particular provision. It is unnecessary to go down the track of the Opposition's amendment in this matter. But, as I have indicated, superfluous though it may be, we do not resist it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Although it is unnecessary for me to intervene further, I would like to say that I have long since given up expecting Senator Haines to please me, but when she does I am nevertheless grateful that the Australian Democrats are going to support us.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —There were two foreshadowed amendments to proposed new sub-section 50 (2C), Senator Siddons to leave out the whole sub-section and Senator Durack to add words at the end of the sub-section. To allow the freest debate, I will give the opportunity to Senator Durack to move his amendment first.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Chairman.
—I would have thought that it would have been more logical to get out of the way a deletion rather than an addition.
—I am in the hands of the Chairman.

—This will allow the freest debate. If Senator Siddons's amendment had been carried, it would have been impossible to debate the desirability of the addition. In this way we can debate the desirability of the addition. If that is added, Senator Siddons can move to delete the whole sub-section.
—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 8, paragraph (e), proposed new sub-section 50 (2C), at end of sub-section, add:

`, unless, in the case of an acquisition of shares, a Part A statement within the meaning of the Companies (Acquisition of Shares) Act 1980 in respect of that acquisition of shares was lodged with the National Companies and Securities Commission in accordance with that Act before the day on which the Trade Practices Amendment Act 1986 received the Royal Assent'.

We have now come to the proposed new sub-section in clause 17 which has attracted so much attention and which is obviously going to lead to a good deal of debate now in Committee. The section which the clause seeks to amend is again section 50, the merger section, which states the general principle that a corporation shall not acquire, directly or indirectly, any shares in the capital, or any assets, of a body corporate if as a result of the acquisition the corporation would be in a position to dominate the market. Those words are the result of an amendment which will be passed shortly and which is contained in other provisions of this clause. That wording was introduced in 1977 and it has the effect of saying that, where there is an attempted acquisition of a body corporate which already is in a position to dominate a market or which, in common parlance, is a monopoly, despite the fact that there was already in existence that monopoly or that degree of market domination, section 50 shall apply whereas section 50 of course is really directed at the prevention of monopolies. The effect would be that a monopoly would be protected further because any attempted takeover of that monopoly would have to go through the process of the Trade Practices Commission taking steps to prevent it if it thought that was required or the person seeking to acquire would have to seek authorisation from the Trade Practices Commission under which he would have a very great burden of proving public benefit.

This really gives rise to an anomalous situation in the case of existing monopolies or near monopolies, and the Government has proposed that a new sub-section (2C) be inserted to eliminate the existing effect of section 50, which says that it will not apply to the acquisition by a person of any shares in the capital or assets of a body corporate where before the acquisition the body corporate was in a position to dominate a market for goods or services and as a result of the acquisition the person is not and is not likely to be in a stronger position to dominate the market. That amendment of the Government is expressing a view with which the Opposition is broadly in agreement. We have expressed this agreement in principle on a number of occasions since the matter first received attention and particularly since the Australian Democrats started to give it attention. We had already considered this matter in the calmer days before the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd take-over proposal was launched by the Bell Group, or by Mr Holmes a Court, as people are more commonly referring to it. The Opposition examined closely these amendments to the Trade Practices Act last October or November, or soon after they were introduced by the Government. Although we have grave objections to the general thrust of this legislation and have already voted against giving it a second reading, and although our preference would be that we were not here considering the Bill in Committee clause by clause, we decided that, if we had to go through a detailed consideration of every clause, line or word, this amendment included in the Bill was appropriate. Indeed, there are a number of other provisions in the Bill which we would be disposed to support if the legislation contained just them and did not contain all the other offensive provisions which we are now in the process of seeking to amend.

This proposed new sub-section is one which we think in principle is quite appropriate. The reason for that is that we do not think a Trade Practices Commission inquiry in the full authorisation context is the right way to tackle a position of this kind, namely, the future ownership of a monopoly or the way in which it is behaving. There may well be some other way in which it could be done rather than by a Trade Practices Commission inquiry. We make no judgment or proposal one way or the other about that. We are simply dealing with the proposal that it should no longer be dealt with by the Trade Practices Commission under its existing charter.

The problem now is that since we came to that conclusion, and indeed long after the debate in the House of Representatives and just before we commenced the debate in the Senate, we had the new phenomenon of the BHP take-over. We are concerned to ensure even-handedness by the Parliament so that people's existing rights and expectations will not be changed by anything we do here right in the middle of the take-over proposals. There are many other things going on as well-the picture is most unclear as to what is going to happen-but certainly we want to ensure that we do not add any further confusion and do not make any changes to the rules of the game as they are now and as they were when the game started. The object of this amendment is to make that quite clear. It applies to any take-over, not just the Bell take-over. We want to make it quite clear that any take-overs that have already been registered-in other words, where there has been a legal step, not just something that has been talked about-will be covered. A legal step has been taken in the case of the BHP take-over. That has been registered. A Part A statement has been registered with the Corporate Affairs Commission of Victoria as agent for the National Companies and Securities Commission. That action has formally and legally commenced the take-over offer process. Despite whatever court proceedings may be going on and whatever delays there may be, the action has commenced. My amendment proposes to ensure that that take-over proposal be dealt with under the law existing at the time the statement was lodged.

There is some legal argument as to whether or not this amendment is necessary and whether or not that would not be the case. There is certainly good argument for a change being made because the ordinary rule of interpretation that private rights not be altered retrospectively by changes in legislation probably does not apply in a case of this kind, where no vested legal right is being claimed or litigated. I concede that there may be two views on that question. There is a real prospect, if we pass this legislation now that the requirement that the Trade Practices Commission look at this probable or possible breach of section 50-that in itself may be argued-because an offer has been made to take over an existing company which has monopolies in certain areas, that that power of the Trade Practices Commission will not be preserved. If we change the law now in the middle of the take-over, the Trade Practices Commission may well decide that action is no longer required. The take-over was launched by the Bell group of companies in the full knowledge of the existing state of the law. Whatever changes might be made to alter it, the fact is that the bid was launched in that context. This take-over which was launched under the law in its present form should continue to be processed under the Trade Practices Act and by the Trade Practices Commission under the law that stood on the day that the Part A statement was lodged with the National Companies and Securities Commission.

If there is some argument, as one may well be advanced, that this is not necessary, it is quite arguable, that the position is uncertain. That in itself is full justification for our amendment, because as legislators, we should not do anything which will leave a state of uncertainty any greater than is necessary. Lawyers may argue until the cows come home on this matter and people have very fervent views on it in one way or another, but what is not arguable or debatable is that the proposed new section is not clear. We want to make it clear. Therefore the sole purpose of my amendment is to make it crystal clear.

This is an important matter. It is a matter of great public interest, a matter of enormous interest, naturally, to the two contestants, Bell and BHP. They want to know where they stand. The Trade Practices Commission needs to know where it stands. It has asked to have a signal from the Parliament. It has issued a most unprecedented statement, and it is our obligation as legislators to give everybody a clear direction. We want to make it perfectly clear that this change in the law that we propose-the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard, has put it very neatly-will not change the rules of the game after the game has started.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me begin by saying something about sub-section 50 (2c) of the Trade Practices Act and why the Government has proposed to act as it has in this respect. If one thing is absolutely clear beyond dispute in this whole argument, it is that existing section 50, dealing as it does with the principle and practice of anti-competitive mergers, is a totally inappropriate means of dealing with bare transfers of monopoly power. Section 50 is and was always intended to be and has in practice always hitherto been applied as a provision about mergers which go to reduce competition in some way.

SPEECH.PARA: The test to be applied under section 50 when it comes to the Trade Practices Commission exercising its capacity to grant authorisations makes that absolutely clear, because the test that is set out in section 50 is a test that is capable of application in any practical sense only in an environment where one begins with a merger or an acquisition which is prima facie anti-competitive. The test that the Commission has to apply in this respect is set out in section 90 (9) of the Trade Practices Act in the following terms:

The Commission shall make a determination granting an authorisation under sub-section 88 (9) in respect of a proposed acquisition of shares in the capital, or assets, of a body corporate unless it is satisfied in all the circumstances that the proposed acquisition would result, or be likely to result, in such a benefit to the public that the acquisition should be allowed to take place.

The test to be applied by the Commission is a test of net public benefit; it is not a test of public detriment, and that is a very significant distinction. The test is premised on a state of affairs where the Commission is confronted with a merger which is prima facie uncompetitive, increasing market dominance and reducing the number of competitors in a particular market, something which, in other words, is of prima facie detriment, given the whole philosophy of the trade practices legislation and our well-established community beliefs about the dangers of monopolies and increased concentration and reduced competition.

The starting point then is something which is pretty clearly detrimental. The task that the Commission has been given in section 90 (9) is the task of weighing against that obvious existing detriment any countervailing benefits which may happen to be clearly evident and determining whether at the end of the day when it balances everything up, the public interest is nonetheless served even though on the face of it, prima facie, there has been a reduction in competition. I suggest that it is only in that context that the concept of a net public benefit test makes any sense at all. To require a net public benefit test to be applied when one is dealing with bare transfers of monopoly power, when by definition there is no reduction in competition, no increase in concentration, no increase in market power and no increase in dominance, is to insulate monopolies permanently and irrevocably from effective attack, from challenge to their entrenched status and from any kind of discipline as a result to improve their performance. That is obviously not in the interests of the economy. The Canberra Times put it very succinctly in its editorial of Wednesday, 5 March, when it stated:
It seems ridiculous that a law which stops the creation of new monopolies should be used to protect existing monopolies.

The notion of its being able to be applied in this way to protect existing monopolies is one that should be anathema in this place. Of course it has been anathema. Once the anomaly in the existing operation of section 50 was understood, the Trade Practices Commission made it clear that it would not, in the exercise of its discretion, apply the section in such a way that it would impact upon bare transfers of monopoly power-unless there was some element of increased concentration or something there which gave rise to competition related concerns. That is why the Trade Practices Commission responded as it did in the Swan Brewery case, which is still about the only case on record of the Trade Practices Commission having addressed the application of section 50 to a bare transfer of monopoly power situation.

So, it has been acknowledged by the Trades Practices Commission, just as it was clearly acknowledged in the debate leading up to the introduction of this legislation, by the Law Council of Australia and other bodies which have an interest in the legislation and have commented upon it. It is worth putting very firmly and very clearly on the record that it has also been acknowledged by the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd itself. I refer to BHP's letter to me on 15 May 1984, when I was Attorney-General, in response to the proposals for change of the Trade Practices Act. On page 3 of that letter, under the heading `Section 50', it says:
As drafted, the proposed new sub-sections (1), (2) and (3) overcome an anomaly in the present Section, in that they will not apply to `bare transfers of monopoly power' . . .

So there it is. We have had BHP on the public record-this is a public document-saying that it regarded the application of the existing section 50 to bare transfers of monopoly power as `an anomaly'. That is a position from which BHP is clearly unable to resile as a conceptual matter, however much it might wish to do so in the circumstances of its present corporate difficulties.

This is, of course, a position which has been accepted all along, comprehensively and unequivocally, by the Opposition and which is still maintained, to the present day, by Senator Durack. There was no opposition at any stage expressed by the Opposition to the proposed change to section 50 during the lengthy, protracted public debate that occurred in the days before this amending Bill was introduced into the Parliament. There was no reference to this particular issue in the debate in the House of Representatives. There was no opposition expressed to this amending clause in the present Bill, sub-section 50 (2C), in the debate in the House of Representatives in November last year. Since then, support for the principle of this legislation has been expressed on a number of occasions, not least by Mr Howard as recently as last night at his Press conference when he said, among other things:

We think it is unnecessary to require authorisation when all that is really happening is a change in the ownership of a monopoly as distinct from some alteration in the concentration of the monopoly power in the market.

Again, further on in the transcript of his remarks he spoke in the context of changing the rules of the game-I will come to that amendment in a moment-and referred to the section 50 amendment proposed by the Government. This attracted the approving reference `good though it is in principle'. So, there is a clear acknowledgment that the amendment is good in principle. The clincher is on page 5 of the transcript of Mr Howard's Press conference, when he said:
I don't mind saying for a moment that the proposed changes to section 50 are essential ones. I've said that. I said that yesterday.

Thus, there is no mystery about this; there is no pretence on the part of the Opposition about the basic changes to section 50, as embodied in the proposed new sub-section (2C), which are sound, properly based in principle and conceptually apt and should proceed.

I take it that it would be quite inconceivable that the Opposition now, today, could change course on the proposed amendment in sub- section (2C) and retain any shred of credibility, should it be minded to do so at a later stage in the debate. I say nothing about the credibility of the Opposition should it choose at some later stage to vote against the third reading of the Bill. We will cross that bridge when we come to it. In the context of the particular change to the sub-section 50 (2C), it is inconceivable, given the support-the perfectly correct support in principle-that the Opposition has expressed for this for so long, that it could now turn around and vote against it. It does not seem-although I am anticipating Senator Siddons's amendment to remove sub-section (2C) entirely-that there will be any difference between the Opposition and the Government on the merits of sub-section (2C) and the amendment that contains to section 50. We are now talking about the amendment to sub-section (2C) which adds a gloss, a tailpiece, an addition to this amending clause. That addition is designed, in the words of both Mr Howard and Senator Durack, to ensure that the rules of the game do not change.

I put it to the Opposition that the rules of the game have not changed so far. Section 50 remains in its present form, notwithstanding the introduction of the legislation into the House of Representatives and the passage of it to the present stage. I further make the point that section 50 will remain in its present form, as a technical legal matter anyway, until such time as this amending legislation is proclaimed. Whether there has been a breach of the rules set out in the present section 50 will depend and depend only on whether there has been an acquisition, not only set in train but also completed, at the time that section 50 in its present form ceases to have effect. The rules of the game remain as they are embodies in the present section 50-I repeat this-until such time as a change to section 50 is accomplished.

TALK.START.PARA: —We might break all records and do that today.

—That does not seem very likely at the present rate of progress. It is not clear what the Opposition is seeking to preserve by this amendment which would not in any event be clearly preserved simply by the operation of the normal legal principles of when laws change and when they do not change.

SPEECH.PARA: The confusion and misunderstanding that are embodied in the Opposition amendment have crept in because there has been a failure to appreciate that section 50 operates on an acquisition. It does not operate on a threatened acquisition or on the very first step that might be taken to acquire shares or the assets of another corporation. The prohibition on an acquisition occurring without authorisation is something that bites only when an acquisition process is complete. The issuing of a Part A statement is not in itself something that attracts the full force of section 50. If one issues a Part A statement without having sought or obtained authorisation, one is not in breach, as such, of section 50. Prima facie, one is not in breach of section 50 until such time as the acquisition process has been completed and completed without a prior authorisation having been received. Those are the rules of the game which Mr Holmes a Court must confront and those rules will not change up to and until the time the amending legislation is proclaimed.

Section 50 is and will remain prima facie applicable up to the time the rules change with the proclamation and the Trade Practices Commission will retain right up to that point exactly the some kind of discretion as it has at the moment as to whether to proceed to act on a threatened breach of section 50 that may or may not occur in the future-a sort of preliminary track that is embarked upon-or to make a decision as to whether, there having been a breach, a subsequent prosecution should be pursued. All those discretions remain available to the Trade Practices Commissioner all the way up until the time that section 50 changes. The notion that one has to put in some kind of language such as this indicating that the rules of the game shall continue to apply to the Holmes a Court transaction, or any other acquisition set in train at some earlier stage, seems to me a misconceived one. Accordingly, the Government's response to this amendment is that it is misconceived and we would oppose it for that reason.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Gareth Evans has spent some considerable time and legal argument trying to convince us that section 50 (1a) is an anomaly in the trade practices legislation. That may or may not be the case. I do not intend to take on Senator Evans's legal arguments. I want rather to review the situation as it applies at the moment. Section 50 (1a) is the law of the land right now. The Trade Practices Commission for the first time in its history has been sufficiently concerned about a take-over of a company in a clear monopoly position to initiate legal action. Therefore, prima facie this Parliament is confronted with a take-over bid of immense proportions. Mr Holmes a Court proposes a takeover of Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd, the largest company in the land and a company in a critical position in three overall areas of our economy, steel, coal and oil. The Trade Practices Commission is sufficiently concerned about the legality of that takeover under the existing law to initiate legal action.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government is saying that there is an anomaly in section 50 (1a). In its defence I must say that the Government has been saying that for a long time. We are not arguing that. That is really not the point at issue. The point at issue is that the rules are being changed. As Senator Durack said, they are being changed at a critical time when the Trade Practices Commission is concerned about the legality of probably the most important take-over bid this country will ever have. Once one man gets control of a company in so dominant a position as BHP, one wonders whether that one man will be in charge of the means of production of the whole of this country.

The Government is moving to neutralise section 50 (1a) while this process is going on. In the meantime, until the Government gets itself in order and it lets us know what sort of approach it is going to make we will not know where we are. If Holmes a Court wanted to get around it all he would have to do is withdraw his present bid and introduce a new one, say, on Monday morning, if this amendment were passed today. Therefore, as far as the Australian Democrats can see, the amendment does not achieve a thing. I do not know whether the amendment has been put before us on the basis of the Opposition's trying to be very subtle or whether it is being put seriously. However, as far as the Australian Democrats can see, such an amendment would not affect the situation at all.

The Trade Practices Commission, which has initiated the legal action at this point under section 50 (1A), presumably would, when a new bid was initiated by Holmes a Court, say, on Monday, if this amendment were passed, not proceed with its legal action and nobody would know what its original objection was. Therefore, for these reasons we will be opposing the Opposition's so-called grandfather amendment, as it has been dubbed by the media.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me deal first with Senator Siddons's opening suggestion that this is the first time in the history of the Trade Practices Commission that it has been sufficiently concerned about an exercise of this kind to initiate legal action. It is the common view that the Trade Practices Commission has hung its hat in a vigorous way on the present takeover situation and in effect has expressed opposition to it, but I think it is pretty important in this debate for us to appreciate just what exactly the TPC has and has not done about this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: In the first place, it undoubtedly has formed a prima facie view that this proposed acquisition, and it is only proposed at this stage, would, if it proceeded to fruition, be in breach of section 50 of the Trade Practices Act because of the way in which section 50 is worded at the moment and because of the way in which that wording has been construed, in particular by Mr Justice Northrop in the Ansett-Avis case-in a very literal-minded way, it must be said in passing; but so be it. The Commission has formed a prima facie view that section 50 in its present form is probably applicable. I add that the TPC has also made its view very publicly apparent on many occasions: It believes the law ought to be changed in this respect and it is no proper part of the TPC's business to be looking at bare transfers and monopoly power, at least under the present machinery provided by the Act, which is wholly inappropriate for that purpose. Certainly that point can be stated. That is the prima facie view that the TPC formed because it felt it had to form that view as the law now stands.

What the Trade Practices Commission has not done yet has been to address its collective mind to the question of whether, even if there is a prima facie breach or a potential breach of section 50, Mr Holmes a Court and the Bell Group Ltd in fact should be pursued in relation to that breach, whether by means of a full and formal inquiry by the TPC itself or through the courts; that is to say, pursued in those ways rather than being subject to the exercise of a discretionary decision, as in the Bond case, not to pursue the matter at all in the proper exercise of the Trade Practices Commission's functions, on the ground that it did not think any public interest purpose would be thereby served.

What the Trade Practices Commission has done at this stage has simply been to preserve the status quo, for perfectly understandable reasons-because of its concern that the situation be clarified-until such time as the Parliament expresses its will on what precisely the Parliament wants to do with proposed new section 50 (2C). The House of Representatives has unanimously expressed a view that it wants 50 (2C) passed and the existing section 50 modified accordingly. This Committee is in the process today of expressing its will on the same subject. What the Trade Practices Commission has done in the courts so far is simply seek an injunction to stop further steps in the acquisition process until such time as the situation is clarified. What the Trade Practices Commission settled for by way of a court order at the first stage of this was, as Senator Durack said, an interlocutory order requiring that Bell not proceed to actually distribute its Part A offer without first giving two days notice to the TPC. It must be appreciated that during those two days that the TPC will then have to work out what it wants to do it will have at large, in terms of its capacity, at that stage to exercise some discretion as to what then ought to happen. No doubt it will be much better informed as to Parliament's will at that stage as a result of this debate here today.

I think it is important not to suggest that the Trade Practices Commission has already in a sense prejudged the actual merits of this issue in terms of the dangers or otherwise to the nation of this takeover proceeding. I think it is understandable that Senator Siddons and others should have construed the public events in this way, but really that is not what has happened. It has simply been a holding action by the TPC. It has felt obliged to take that course by the state of the law as articulated by Mr Justice Northrop and by the uncertain state of what Parliament would do with this. It clearly has not formed a view or stopped to exercise any discretion as to what actually should happen in the circumstances of this case.

Let me come back to Senator Durack's amendment. What I want to say again about the amendment is that it adds nothing except further confusion to an already confused situation. If the Trade Practices Commission is looking for a signal of Parliament's intention, Parliament's views, about proposed new section 50 (2C), I cannot think of a more odd and confused signal to send than the one that Senator Durack is now proposing. If we pass his amendment the signal flowing to the Trade Practices Commission from this Parliament, from that decision and this debate, I guess will be in three parts. The first part of the signal will be that Parliament thinks overwhelmingly that section 50 ought not to apply to bare transfers of monopoly power because it is totally inappropriate for the anti-competitive provisions of the Act, with the net public benefit there contained, to apply to a takeover which, whatever else it involves, does not seem to involve any addition to monopoly power or any reduction in competition.

The second signal the Commission will get is that Parliament acknowledges that section 50 operates only to prohibit completed acquisitions. That is the only possible way one can read the law and that is the point of my earlier intervention in this debate-to point out that section 50 might have a prospective application which could found an injunction, certainly, but it does not take effect, which means there is no prohibition, unless and until there is a completed acquisition. So it will get that signal from this debate. The third signal it will get, if the Durack amendment is accepted, is that Parliament nonetheless takes the view that section 50 should apply to a particular acquisition now in train but not yet completed.

TALK.START.PARA: —All acquisitions.

—No. It should apply to any acquisition which is presently on the stocks, in the form of some Part A statement having been registered, up until the time that this Bill is proclaimed as an Act. Parliament takes the view that proposed section 50 ought to apply to those kinds of acquisitions which are not yet completed and in most instances will not be complete by the time the Bill is proclaimed. It seems to me to be a very odd set of signals to be sending. Far from it being a matter of not changing the rules of the game, it seems to me, on a proper analysis, that it amounts to an exposure of one particular player in the game-maybe there are others as well-who has an acquisition in train to an additional burden which would not apply to this person if the operation of the law took its ordinary course. It is a burden which is not reasonable in the circumstances and which it is not desirable in the public interest that person should bear; Parliament having expressed the view that it is not in the public interest that bare transfers and monopoly power be exposed as a general rule to this kind of inquiry or authorisation procedure.

SPEECH.PARA: If Parliament has taken that view in principle and is applying it to an acquisition which is not yet complete, an acquisition in respect of which legal rights and obligations have accrued but an acquisition which is still pending, it seems to me that we are applying to a particular player-there may be others as well who have Part A statements outstanding-a burden which is simply discriminatory and is not understandable except as an exercise in somehow wanting to single out that particular player for discriminatory treatment. Mr Holmes a Court is big enough, old enough and strong enough to look after himself. I do not think he needs any help from anyone in that respect; he has demonstrated that over the years.

The document read as follows-
For Media...11 March 1986

Takeovers of public companies are matters normally left to the judgment of the market subject to compliance with the takeovers code (which is directed to investor protection and fairness) and other relevant legislation.

The Government decided that, in the particular circumstances of Bell's current takeover bid for BHP, a committee of Ministers should hold detailed discussions with representatives of each of the companies.
As a result of these discussions, the Government is satisfied as to the future integrity of the Steel Plan. Attached are copies of the relevant assurances provided by both parties.

As to the revenue implications of the proposed takeover, the Government does not believe, on all the information and advice available to it, that there are any public interest considerations presently apparent which would justify intervention.

In relation to the Trade Practices Act, nothing has emerged which would lead the Government to change its position on the amendment to section 50 which has passed the House of Representatives and is now before the Senate.
It would not be appropriate for the Government to comment further while the bid is before the market and related issues are before the courts.
ATTACHMENT B
The following are the assurances provided by Bell Resources Limited on the Steel Industry Plan:
``Contained in our take-over offer is a formal commitment to support the Government Steel Plan.
I understand this to be substantially a commitment to:
(a) no involuntary redundancies before 1989;
(b) the continuation of the three integrated steel plants at Newcastle, Wollongong, and Whyalla;
(c) a substantial capital investment programme by BHP of approximately $1.5 billion of which $900 million has either been spent or approved.

I would regard these commitments and the tripartite co-operative agreement between the Company, the Government and the Unions to be minimum commitments and to represent the base for future growth and capital investment aimed at ensuring the long term viability and integrity and competitiveness of that industry.

Ideally, the steel industry should aim to be sufficiently competitive to compete in export markets bearing in mind that many of these markets are State owned, subsidised or have present surplus capacity.

Penetration of these markets can be achieved in two major ways. Firstly, as a result of sheer price competitiveness and, secondly, by developing down stream capacity in other countries relying upon Australia for raw material or unfinished products.
BHP has an obligation to ensure that the industry does not again fall into the state of disrepair in which it found itself three years ago.
Apprenticeship programmes and other educational programmes are an axiomatic obligation that falls to the major employer in an industry to ensure the steady supply of skilled manpower.

I have read the A.I.S. Colliers Rationalisation Plan dated the 14th June 1985 and can confirm that although I have no first hand knowledge of the factors involved I would not seek to disrupt BHP's present commitments.

While my commitment represents a clear and genuine expression of present intent I believe that it cannot be varied in the future simply upon the basis that some new and unforeseen factor is present. In such an event I believe that BHP cannot simply act unilaterally. It would need to convince both the Government and the Unions that major changes are warranted.''

It seems that the Democrats are seeking to have the take over postponed to the point where it will inhibit and frustrate Mr Holmes a Court and that in itself will be of advantage to BHP. If that is the machiavellian motive behind the Democrats' proposal, it seems to me that by any measure they do not have a neutral position.

TALK.START.PARA: —How are you neutral, with what you said about BHP yesterday as reported in Hansard?

—My view of BHP's management was articulated in a very powerful and persuasive speech, which I am sorry that Senator Chipp did not hear, when the steel plan was introduced. The steel plan was introduced was to rescue and bail out BHP because of periods of--
—`The most inefficient and incompetent bunch that has ever been in control of shareholders' funds'. You said that.

—I must say BHP has improved in the last two years since it has been under some sort of threat of a take over. It is amazing how a little competition can make a company very efficient and very sensitive. Prior to that period its inefficiency was notorious. One has only to read through the Industries Assistance Commission recommendations on the subsidy on steel to reinforce that argument. In terms of this takeover we are absolutely neutral. I do not resile from the position I put with respect to BHP management which caused the demise of the steel industry. At a time when there was an oversupply of steel, world demand for steel was dropping off dramatically and overseas companies were closing down their plants, BHP was still expanding. I thought the company showed fundamental inefficiency at that time. I put it to the Democrats that their concern for the steel industry has not always been demonstrated in their performance in this chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —If Senator Crichton-Browne had taken the trouble to sit in the chamber through the debate on this Bill, instead of just coming in at the last minute, he would have known that the Australian Democrats are not taking sides in the dispute between Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd and Mr Holmes a Court. We are saying simply that there should be a public inquiry; that there is a very dramatic public interest at stake and the public has a right to hear all sides of the story.

TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. I refer the Minister to comments attributed to him in Paul Kelly's article in today's Australian on the J curve and to the Minister's alleged view, expressed in that article, about the difficulties of turning round traditional Australian industry and that there is a whole generation of smaller companies and newer managers with different attitudes. I think the Minister is saying that these people are the hope for the future. Are not these smaller companies and their managers likely to be the most severely disadvantaged and discouraged by the Government's proposals for capital gains tax, fringe benefits tax and the superannuation deal with the Australian Council of Trade Unions? Does the Minister agree that these Government impositions go against the sort of entrepreneurial upsurge that he is evidently seeking from these smaller businesses?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not read Paul Kelly's article in today's Australian; so I do not know what remarks can be correctly attributed to me. I am not in a position to affirm or deny them. I think it would be safer for me to say that I would probably deny them, but I will not do that because the question really has a different point. I am sure I have said that there are many smaller, very innovative companies in Australia which have a newer generation of management and which are very important to this country and will be increasingly so in the future.

ANSWER.PARA: I was then asked whether those companies would be disadvantaged and discouraged by the capital gains tax, the fringe benefits tax and the proposed superannuation case before the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. In relation to the fringe benefits tax, I am sure that some of the businesses will suffer some mild disadvantage from their incapacity to have free lunches or lunches at the taxpayers' expense.

TALK.START.PARA: —Additional tax burdens are involved.

—I have not finished the answer. Of course there are other elements of the fringe benefits tax which may or may not impinge on them, depending upon the nature of their business. In dealing with taxation issues and the alleged disadvantages, one must look at the tax package as a whole and take account of the views expressed very widely by economists and the views expressed most cogently in papers such as the Australian Financial Review, that the tax package as a whole will bring very great benefits to Australian industry in the sense that it will discourage investment in non-productive activities and encourage investment in industry--
—Which industries?

—Not the Surfers Paradise flat industry, but Australian industry. I do not propose to spend Question Time answering Senator Messner, but if he wants that sort of material I will be happy to give it to him. I am surprised that, as Opposition spokesman on finance, he has not read it, because it is quite freely available.

ANSWER.PARA: In terms of imputation, lower marginal rates and things like that, there will be considerable benefits to people in a number of these businesses. A number of other things that the Government has done will be of immense benefit to people in those sorts of businesses. The improved depreciation allowance, the tax concession for research and development and the revised export market development grants scheme will all be of benefit to a lot of people in businesses of that kind. Of course, in a sense there are swings and roundabouts.

I do not think that Question Time is necessarily the best opportunity to be anecdotal, but let me just say this: A week ago I went to the launch at one of these small businesses of a very sophisticated new laser cutting machine tool which was made by a company with a total staff of 35, 12 of whom are qualified engineers. The machine that was launched was going to Germany where it had been sold. The company concerned is talking about taking the Swedes out of the United Kingdom market within two years with that product. It is a very good, innovative company. The managing director of that company made a speech-I did not have any input into it or solicit it; it was made to a wide-ranging business audience-in which he simply made the point about the importance of research and development, about innovation and engineering skills in companies of this kind. He went on to say that in manufacturing Australia was not placed at any competitive disadvantage, in terms of labour costs, when compared with Germany, the United Kingdom and Sweden. They were the three countries he mentioned. He went on further to make the point that his work force had been working until midnight the night before in order to get the final packaging on the machine--

TALK.START.PARA: —They were polishing it up for the Minister.

—Senator Chaney says that they were polishing it up for me. I would like to think that was so, but I would not be so presumptuous. Because this is also a very good marketing company, I would have thought that they were polishing it up for the customer. That is another important facet. The simple point I am making about this is that those people who are in there battling it out do not always assume the gloomy rhetoric and see all the inhibitions which the lugubrious Senator Messner, who is sitting opposite me, sees for businesses of this kind. There are a lot of such companies around and they are--
—Let us remember that we are competing in Asia.

—Senator Messner reminds us that we are competing in Asia. I do not know what follows from that. Perhaps he will tell us some time. Those who are out there with new management and new attitudes, who are very aggressive and who see themselves as operating in international markets are the companies that will succeed. They do not go on, in speeches to their colleagues in the business community, about the sorts of things that have been raised in Senator Chaney's question.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Special Minister of State. Does the Minister agree with recent allegations that the New South Wales Government has emasculated the National Crime Authority? Is New South Wales co-operating with the NCA?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Allegations that the National Crime Authority, the premier body for fighting organised crime in this country, is being hindered by a State government are very serious and it is appropriate that they should be raised for response by Senator Tate who played such a central and constructive role in chairing the Senate committee on the National Crime Authority Bill. Mr Young has advised me that he can see no substance at all in the allegations. The New South Wales Government has requested the NCA to investigate a number of major organised crime matters and has issued to the Authority the two formal State references so far requested by the Authority. In respect of these matters the NCA, and Commonwealth and NSW agencies are co-operating fully and effectively. In Mr Young's briefings with the members of the Authority they have indicated that they are very happy with the level of co-operation with the NSW authorities. The Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police has also stated to the Minister that the degree of co-operation with the NSW Police and its Minister is very satisfactory.

ANSWER.PARA: As to States preventing the NCA investigating matters under its general powers, apart from references, the NCA can of its own volition and without any need for approvals investigate relevant criminal activities in any jurisdiction. In order to use its special coercive powers, however, the NCA requires the approval of a State government before it can investigate matters within that State's jurisdiction using those powers. Proposed State references must, therefore, be approved by the Minister representing the State on the Inter-governmental Committee on the NCA. The Inter-governmental Committee has resolved to announce publicly any case where a reference sought by the NCA is refused by it. The State concerned would then have to defend its decision in public. Obviously, no such circumstance has yet arisen. I repeat the substance of the response that there is simply no foundation in the allegations that have been made.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services. I ask: Can the Minister explain the increase by almost 30 per cent in the cost of the construction of the Beijing Embassy in the period April 1984 to March 1986, escalating the cost from an estimated $37.4m to a reported $48.5m? As the construction of the embassy is not due to begin until March 1987, can the Minister inform us as to what further cost the Australian taxpayer will be subjected to and what the final estimates will be on completion of the embassy by late 1989. How does the Government justify the expenditure of an estimated $76m until completion on current prices of a property which, firstly, cannot be sold and a gain made on the capital spent and, secondly, will be too small to house Australian staff after the year 2000-only 11 years from the proposed completion date?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not have any specific information in my brief about the proposals in respect of the Australian Embassy in the People's Republic of China. I have sought the information but it has not yet been made available to me. However, I can say that the Government's long term aim is to contain the rental bill in foreign countries by acquiring or constructing a higher proportion of publicly owned properties. To this end the Government is continuing a program of removing the increasing cost of accommodation in foreign countries. For example, $75m was spent on overseas properties during the year 1984-85. Of that amount some $33m was spent on renting properties for Australian embassies abroad.

ANSWER.PARA: It is pretty clear that it is in the long term interests of Australia that we acquire properties in our own right, in particular in countries with which we are going to have long term trade and economic and social interchange and relationships. I would have thought that any steps taken to reach the objectives I have referred to in respect of the People's Republic of China would be understood by honourable senators and would be supported by them. It is pretty clear that there is a tremendous market opening up in that country and that we therefore need to have the human and other resources there to fulfil those long term trade objectives. However, as I have said, I have not got the specific information, even though I have requested it, in respect of Senator Hill's question to me. I hope that before Question Time concludes I will be able to answer it more precisely.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security. Is the Minister familiar with the Gold Coast based organisation called Safeguard Australia? Has the Minister's attention been drawn to a recent statement in the Gold Coast Bulletin by the director of that organisation, Mr Charles Connolly, suggesting that the supporting parent's benefit has become a reward for promiscuity? Can the Minister advise the Senate how the Government views these rather extraordinary claims and, further, whether the Federal Government is committed to continuing to provide pensions to supporting parents?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —My attention has been drawn to the organisation apparently based on the Gold Coast in Queensland called Safeguard Australia and the particularly vicious and destructive comments the spokesperson for that organisation, Mr Connolly, is reported as having made in the Gold Coast Bulletin of 5 March this year. I can only regret that the poorest people in our community, those who are struggling hardest, namely, single supporting parents, are subjected to this kind of attack and that the media is prepared to promote it, or at least to give it space.

ANSWER.PARA: I think every honourable senator in this place is aware that any examination of poverty reveals that the poorest people in this community are single supporting parents struggling to bring up children. It is true that the cost of government support for these poor families is very great but it is also true that there is no group in the community that has a greater claim for assistance by government. Far from having any intention to reduce assistance to this particularly disadvantaged group, our Government has managed to increase pension payments to this group in each Budget and to increase the benefits paid for the additional support for children of single supporting parents.

At the same time it is true to say that we do not regard the existence of pensions as a desir- able permanent state of affairs for these families. Many of our other programs are directed towards giving single parents the opportunity to get training and skills and employment. For example, our community employment program, which has been enormously successful in contributing to the creation of more than half a million jobs in the last three years, has an outstanding record in providing jobs to women. I think that over 50 per cent of jobs now, certainly in many aspects of the program, have gone to women, many of whom, of course, are single supporting parents.

Similarly, an increasing proportion of funds allocated by us to technical and further education colleges is being directed to special bridging courses, access courses, which enable women with no skills and very little education-again, very often single supporting parents, the very unfair subject of this attack by this right wing organisation-to move into a situation where they will be able to come off the pension and gain secure employment. The Government has also announced and commenced a major inquiry into income security which is being conducted through the Social Security portfolio. It will examine all aspects of poverty and the income needs of those in poverty. Again, this group of single parents supporting children will be a major concern of that inquiry.

The Senate might also be interested to hear that parallel to this inquiry the Government is conducting an inquiry into maintenance. Failure to pay maintenance, as all honourable senators would know, is one of the contributions to the poverty in which this group exists. It is of great concern to our Government that many parents who are in a position to support their children and their former partners do not do so and are able to evade their maintenance responsibilities. Therefore, the burden for assisting these families falls entirely on the public purse. That is not a fair or equitable state of affairs. The purpose of the inquiry into maintenance which we are now conducting is to find ways in which we can ensure that parents who are able to contribute to the support of their children and their former partners in fact do so. By this means of course we will be assisting many in the single parent population to improve their standard of living. At the same time, I should make it clear that we have no intention of placing any additional burdens on single parents and their children by way of their having to take the responsibility for seeking maintenance. Rather we are looking at ways in which government agencies can do that effectively.

So we accept that we have a responsibility to this poorest group in the community. We have no intention of withdrawing support. We have every intention of assisting them to improve their circumstances and trying to get a more responsible performance in maintenance payment by those parents able to do so. I say in conclusion that, again, it is very regrettable that this most vulnerable group is subjected to smear campaigns the likes of which are perpetrated by the right wing organisation called Safeguard Australia. I think it behoves every representative of a political party in this place to disassociate themselves from attacks of this kind.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. Is the Government aware that virtually all insurance policies covering Australian homes and their contents, and motor vehicles, have a nuclear exclusion-that is, the insurance company does not provide a cover for damage caused by or contributed to by any kind of nuclear accident due to nuclear fuel, nuclear waste or nuclear weapons? To what extent does the United States Government accept liability for damage which might be caused as a result of an accident to one of its nuclear war ships visiting an Australian city? Do Federal or State governments accept any share of that liability? Is it likely that millions of Australians would lose everything they had, without compensation, in the event of such an accident, even, perhaps, just an escape of radiation? What does the Government propose to do about that situation?

—I think I had a brief on this some time ago, but it has taken Senator Mason a while to get around to asking his question. I might need to get some further information on that before responding, with the gravity that is necessary for a question of such importance.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security. Which unemployed Australians will benefit from the overdue extension of rent assistance to social security beneficiaries in May? What will be the cost to revenue of this significant anti-poverty measure? How many unemployed Australians will benefit?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —From May 1986 rental assistance of up to $10 a week will be available to unemployed and to special beneficiaries aged 18 years or more who pay private rent and have been in receipt of benefit for at least six months. It will be payable to those under 25 years old only if beneficiaries are not living with a parent or guardian. This initiative will assist in reducing pressure on emergency relief agencies which have found private renters to be a high proportion of their clients. This new form of assistance is another example of our Government's determination to target assistance where it is most needed.

ANSWER.PARA: As announced in the context of assistance for youth, separate arrangements will be developed to provide appropriate levels of help for the 16- to 17-year-olds who are unable to get support from their parents. The extension of rent assistance to the unemployed is estimated to cost some $10m in 1985-86, and $59m in a full year.

This decision will be reinforced by the Government's recent decision to alleviate the poverty traps as a part of the tax reform package. From November 1986, the abolition of the separate income test on rent assistance will mean that those in private rental accommodation will not lose 50c of rent assistance for every dollar they earn, thus making a substantial improvement in their circumstances. Finally, an estimated 115,000 unemployment and special beneficiaries will receive rent assistance.
