—Can the Minister representing the Treasurer advise the Senate whether bankruptcy figures are now available for the year 1985? If so, can the Minister further advise the Senate what conclusions can be drawn from these figures?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The figures on bankruptcies are available for 1985. They show that in New South Wales, Victoria, South Australia, Western Australia and the Australian Capital Territory the number of non-corporate bankruptcies in 1985 was down by 0.7 per cent on the 1984 figure. The picture was different in other parts of Australia. In the Northern Territory, for example, the 1985 figure was up by 103 per cent.
—How much?

—I will repeat that-103 per cent; more than double the 1984 figure. In Queensland the increase was 22 per cent, and in Tasmania it was 21 per cent. It will have been noticed, of course, that those States where there was a very large to enormous increase in the bankruptcy rate are all governed by non-Labor governments. Because of that fact, the national figure was up by 5.6 per cent, despite the better performance in all the Labor States.

ANSWER.PARA: As a matter of interest, it ought to be noted in passing that the latest Australian Bureau of Statistics employment figures showed that the unemployment rate in the States is highest in Queensland at 10.3 per cent, and in Tasmania at 9.7 per cent; the rate in both of those non-Labor States being higher than the rate in any other State.

Senator Sibraa has asked me what conclusion should be drawn from those statistics. The obvious conclusion is that the non-Labor States have a very bad record so far as bankruptcy is concerned. Given that the Northern Territory and Tasmania, being small in population, have little effect on the national average, the other conclusion is, of course, that Queensland is dragging Australia down. As in so many other areas, it is Queensland that is dragging Australia down.

Another conclusion to which this points is that Queensland is to an alarming degree displaying the attributes of a banana republic, including capricious leadership. The Premier recently introduced legislation to outlaw strikes in exporting industries, and the same Premier in 1980 supported the coal strike in Queensland against the aim of changing government policy of the day. There are so many of these banana republic systems visible in Queensland that some people have been drawn to draw conclusions between the regime there and the previous regime in the Philippines. One must wonder whether that is the reason for the Premier's close association with East-West Airlines Ltd.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator was asked about bankruptcies. I ask him to come to the point.
—I am rounding off the question, Mr President. The Premier might need that to skip the country, but I wonder whether Senator Bjelke-Petersen has 2,200 pairs of shoes as well.

—I ask a question of the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. In view of the revelation that the Australian Department of Defence said it could not provide the necessary resources for an outstanding scientific exercise, what was the estimated cost of providing intermittent night-time landing facilities for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration's Kuiper airborne observatory at Richmond air base-which has now been transferred to New Zealand in order to facilitate the scientific collaboration between Australia and the United States in the study of Halley's Comet and other issues? Did the Department of Defence provide night-time landing facilities for the airborne observatory's last visit in June 1983? If so, at what cost?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised by the Minister that there would be some quantifiable costs to the Royal Australian Air Force in the provision of supporting equipment and building space during the proposed NASA deployment. These costs, however, were not a significant consideration in the decision that RAAF support to the deployment could be provided only in normal airfield operating hours. While not quantifiable in dollar terms, the critical and unacceptable cost to Air Force operations would have been the imposition of additional load on the constrained manpower establishment already fully committed to defence tasking.

ANSWER.PARA: Another unquantifiable cost would have been the environment impact on local residents of repeated night operations by a large jet aircraft such as the C141 over a period in excess of two months. The answer to the latter part of Senator Archer's question as to precedences of this sort of thing is yes, support was provided by Royal Australian Air Force base Richmond, albeit at some manpower detriment, in a climate of lesser manpower restrictions than currently apply. The cost of this support, although not specifically identified, is considered to have been minimal.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Aviation. The Minister will be aware of recent publicity on the issue of smoking in aircraft. In recent years there have been significant reductions in the flight space available to smokers. Has the Minister given consideration to restricting further the amount of space available?

—I think all senators would be aware that there is increasing community concern about smoking in public places, particularly places where there are some restrictions on the movement of air, such as in aircraft. There is no doubt that the aviation industry has taken this into account in making available non-smoking areas in both first class and economy class areas, and in Trans Australia Airlines business class areas. As I understand it, the ratios are: On Ansett Airlines of Australia flights, 75:25 non-smoking to smoking; on TAA flights, 70:30 in favour of non-smokers. I understand that the Minister for Aviation has written to the airlines suggesting that there is a case to be made out for their taking some initiatives on a commercial basis. Perhaps the first airline to make its aircraft completely non-smoking will capture that increasingly concerned public and therefore gain a commercial advantage over other airlines. So far the three companies concerned-Ansett, TAA and East-West Airlines Ltd-have not been prepared to make that decision. I am sure that all people who travel in aircraft have often noticed that the non-smoking area in an aircraft is full of passengers and the smoking area has only a small number of passengers. One would imagine that ultimately a commercial decision will be made that will meet Senator Child's objectives.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Aviation aware that under the Government's proposed policy of full cost recovery for the Department of Aviation the charges of some small airlines would increase by more than 400 per cent? Is he aware that for the small Airlines of Tasmania Pty Ltd organisation the charges would increase from some $60,000 to almost $317,000 per annum? Does he agree that such an increase obviously will be a financial disaster for the airline and the communities that rely upon the air transport that that airline provides? Will the Minister suspend the introduction of the charges until discussions are held with this airline and any others that are similarly affected?

—The question relates to policy considerations and I am not able to give Senator Townley a satisfactory answer from my briefs. I will take the question on notice and ask the Minister to give the honourable senator an early response.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Special Minister of State. I refer the Minister to the International Police Associations Conference which is planned to be held in Adelaide from 6 to 10 October this year. I ask: Is it a fact that representatives of the South African Police Force are planning to attend the conference? Is it also a fact that New Zealand refused to host members of the South African delegation? Will the Australian Government intervene to prevent representatives from the repressive South African regime from attending this Conference?
—I am afraid I am having a bad day with my briefs. Senator Bolkus will have to wait until the end of Question Time for an answer to that question.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Is the Government aware of the recent demand in the United States Congress that economic sanctions be applied against Ethiopia unless an independent commission is allowed to monitor resettlement camps where, it is alleged, 1,000 people a day are dying from malnutrition? Secondly, what consideration has the Australian Government given to the implementation of this suggestion by us? Thirdly, what independent evidence has the Government obtained from our embassy in Ethiopia and aid organisations in relation to the present situation in Ethiopia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is concerned about reports of human rights abuses in Ethiopia, including those associated with the implementation of the resettlement program, and is aware of United States Government concern that the resettlement program be suspended pending independent investigation of the reports and rectification of abuses. The Australian Government is not aware of United States congressional demands for economic sanctions as such against Ethiopia. The United States hopes to have considered at the current session of the United Nations Commission on Human Rights a resolution calling upon appropriate relief and rehabilitation agencies of the United Nations to ensure that their funds are used in a manner consistent with basic human rights principles and in particular to ensure that no funds are used for the resettlement program until it can be shown that the program does not involve coercion or the involuntary separation of families and is otherwise satisfactory from a humanitarian point of view.

ANSWER.PARA: The Australian delegation has been instructed to support the United States resolution at the Commission on Human Rights. The Government endorses the view that the resettlement program must be managed humanely, efficiently and in accordance with basic human rights principles. Our concerns in this area have already been made known to the Human Rights Commission in the course of our general debate statement. Australia's support for the resolution does not imply a desire for a reduction in multilateral assistance to Ethiopia. The Government remains committed, with other countries and donor agencies, to providing humanitarian assistance to Ethiopia for use in areas of greatest humanitarian need. As to the last part of the question, representatives of Australian non-government organisations and other aid agencies involved in Ethiopia have discussed the situation there with Australian officials, in both Canberra and Addis Ababa, on numerous occasions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations concur with recent estimates that Australian industry is likely to experience a shortage of up to 268,000 computer personnel during the next two decades? Can the Minister say to what extent the Government has allowed for the development of computer management skills in current education and training programs?

—I understand that the estimate to which Senator Elstob referred was the highest of a range of estimates that had been prepared by the National Institute of Labour Studies for a seminar sponsored by IBM Australia Ltd. In fact, the estimates of what will be the situation by 2001 range from an oversupply of 24,000, in round figures, to a shortage of 286,000. The estimates are essentially illustrative in nature, defining a range of possible outcomes, and they are heavily dependent on trends in economic and labour market conditions, developments in computer technology, levels of computer education and training and so on. However, demand for skilled computer personnel has risen sharply during the past two years in response to the general economic recovery brought about by the successful policies of this Government. Growth in demand, however, has varied according to skill levels and experience. Some shortages of high level and specialist skills are now being reported. The Government is responding to those shortages in a number of ways. Firstly, it is seeking to bring to Australia up to 500 unsponsored programmers and analysts this financial year. Secondly, priority is being given to action to meet future requirements for computer related skills as far as possible from domestic sources through higher education institutions, increased training and so on.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. Is it not a fact that in 1974 the people of Australia defeated the concept of one vote one value in a democratic elections referendum which was put to the people of Australia by the then Prime Minister, Mr Whitlam? Why, then, is this Labor Government blatantly overriding the view expressed by the people of Australia in doing a deal with the Australian Democrats to introduce separate legislation designed to enforce one vote one value on the Queensland electoral system? Is it not a fact that a constitutional alteration expressly rejected by the people is to be brought into effect by the back door? Is the Government prepared to deal with this issue democratically by putting the question to the people of Queensland once again through a referendum and, in so doing, not to grossly abuse the external affairs power?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the case that there was an unsuccessful referendum in 1974 on the subject, as I recall, of direct elections and equal electoral boundaries.
—Only 22 years ago.

—Twelve years ago. It seems like a long time, I know. That referendum was defeated, as I recall, following a quite disgraceful campaign of scaremongering and misrepresentation by the forces of darkness opposite, amply represented still in this chamber--
—It was a ripper.

—In a peculiarly beefy and loud fashion by Senator Withers. It is my recollection also, although I stand to be corrected on this, that the referendum did not give itself the best possible chance of succeeding since the formula chosen for equal sized boundaries was population rather than voters, or the other way around. Whatever it was, it did not appear to be attractive to a number of people at the time.

ANSWER.PARA: Whatever the circumstances of history may be, the reality of the matter is that in Australia today we have a quite disgraceful electoral situation. It is clear that the situation in Queensland is such that the only conceivable way in which Senator Bjelke-Petersen's husband could expect to stay in power for any longer period in the future is as a result of being propped up by a squalid and undemocratic gerrymander of unprecedented proportions. Those circumstances exist in other parts of the country-one in particular, as we are all aware-and there is an overwhelming case in principle for doing something about the matter. TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Mason asked me a question today about nuclear accidents. I am able to give him the answer now as follows: Compensation arrangements in the unlikely event of a nuclear reactor or nuclear weapons accident on board a visiting United States warship are set out in part 3 of Mr Beazley's response to House of Representatives question on notice No. 629, published in the House of Representatives Hansard on 10 September 1985, at page 457. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the text of that answer.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows-

In the unlikely event of an accident involving a nuclear reactor or a nuclear weapon, Australia is responsible for the overall command, control and co-ordination of the emergency response. The US and UK would provide the maximum assistance practicable. Under Public Law 93-513 the United States accepts absolute liability for nuclear damage which results from a nuclear incident involving the reactor of a United States warship. The UK Government has provided a unilateral assurance to Australia on reactor accident liability comparable to that given by the United States.

Any claims for compensation resulting from a nuclear weapons accident would be dealt with through diplomatic channels in accordance with customary procedures for settlement of claims under generally accepted principles of law and equity. In the case of the United States, settlement of claims would take place in accordance with Article 12 of the Agreement between Australia and the US concerning the status of US Forces in Australia.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Gietzelt) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
The Australian Federal Police Amendment Bill 1986 is intended to ensure the more effective operation and administration of the Australian Federal Police (AFP).
One of the functions the AFP is currently required to perform is the protection of persons from time to time considered under threat, including ministers of the crown, judges and witnesses.

At present it is not clear that the powers conferred on the members of the AFP under section 9 of the Act adequately cover this protective function if it is performed outside the Australian Capital Territory and beyond the limits of Commonwealth places in the States and the Northern Territory.

At present, section 9 gives a member of the AFP the powers and duties of an officer of the police in the State in which the member is acting only in relation to certain functions of the AFP. The Bill would extend these functions to include the safeguarding of Commonwealth interests, thereby giving members of the AFP clear power to discharge the protective function.
In recent years one of the more valuable tools used by the police in the fight against the drug trade is the use of dogs to detect illicit drugs.

No provision is made in the AFP Act or in any other Commonwealth legislation to govern the use of police dogs. Most jurisdictions prohibit or restrict the access of animals to a number of areas. Clearly, there are occasions when the use of police dogs in otherwise restricted places will be highly desirable.

Accordingly, an amendment is proposed which would provide that a police dog under the control of a police dog handler may lawfully be in any place where it is lawful for the handler to be, in his capacity as a member of the AFP.
This does not give any new rights of entry to the police. It simply allows a police dog to accompany its handler.

There are occasions when a member of the AFP is seconded to a State police force or to another relevant body or organisation, or where a member of the AFP is given special leave to undertake service with a foreign government or with certain institutions or to undertake studies or research.

Sections 33 and 34 of the Act enable arrangements to be made for secondment or special leave. It is not clear, however, whether members seconded under section 33 or given special leave under section 34 have the powers of an AFP member or are subject to disciplinary provisions normally applicable to AFP members.

Provisions of this Bill will make it clear that a seconded member retains powers as an AFP member and is subject to the disciplinary provisions. For members on leave of absence the disciplinary provisions will apply, with the exception of members granted leave to serve as members of the Australian Federal Police Association.

The amendment to section 29 of the Act will permit transfer of the administration of AFP promotion appeals and management initiated retirement and redeployment appeals to the merit protection and review agency, in keeping with the object for which the agency was established.
Finally, an amendment to section 70 of the AFP Act is proposed to permit the making of regulations in relation to the disposal of unclaimed property.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting for lunch I was making the point that the Australian Democrats are not taking sides in the dispute as to whether Mr Holmes a Court or the existing board of the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd should run that company. What we are saying is that it is a matter of grave public importance to the community at large, to the shareholders of BHP and, indeed, to the defence of this country and, as such, there should be a public inquiry. I also made the point, in response to an interjection by Senator Crichton-Browne that the Democrats, and I, in particular, presumably, are not in favour of takeovers, that that is not the case. We simply say that any takeovers that may involve a public interest should be investigated before a tribunal. Some takeovers, of course, are beneficial to the economy. We have no intention of saying, and we never have said, anything along the lines that takeovers should not be allowed to proceed.

SPEECH.PARA: We saw the amazing spectacle two weeks ago of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Federal President of the Australian Labor Party, Mr Wran, being overruled by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) on intervention in the BHP case before the Cabinet had met to decide the issue. On Friday night Mr Hawke and Mr Wran were calling for an inquiry. By Monday they had changed their tune because the world's most acclaimed Treasurer disagreed with them. All this was dressed up by claiming that Robert Holmes a Court had given assurances that BHP would not be broken up and that no retrenchments would occur. I can only say that we must have an incredibly gullible or dangerously naive Prime Minister and Cabinet if they accept those assurances. The facts of the matter are that no director of a public company can give assurances that are binding upon a public company. The only way that can be done is by a resolution of the board of directors. All of Mr Holmes a Court's assurances have been predicated by saying: `I would do this; I would do that'. Those assurances essentially are worthless. If we are supposed to sit back here and accept that the Government has received assurances which cannot be made public because they could be sub judice, that is a pretty sad state of affairs for the Parliament and the running of this country.

Of course, the history of Mr Holmes a Court's assurances to all kinds of bodies before he has involved himself in raids on important public companies is that very few of those assurances have been kept. That is a matter of public record; it is not a matter of BHP spreading rumours, as the Government is trying to get across. It is a matter of public record that Holmes a Court has made all kinds of promises before a take-over about not retrenching staff and about not selling off subsidiaries and has not kept them. No one person can give those assurances. Situations change; companies go broke; they run out of cash; they have to sell subsidiaries; and they have to worry about their cash flows. All that is in the future. One cannot give categorical assurances that people will not be retrenched or that a subsidiary will not be sold. Holmes a Court has no right to give those promises, he is not in a position to give them, and the Government should take no credence from them. Senator Chipp asked the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) where the $2 billion of foreign money being used to finance this take-over is coming from.

TALK.START.PARA: —The original source.

—The original sources. We know that Mr Holmes a Court is being backed by the Chartered Bank of Great Britain, which has a long history of close association with South Africa and the diamond industry in that country, so it is not unreasonable for us to wonder whether there are any strings attached to this $2 billion loan. That is more money than the Government could afford to expend on honouring a promise to the Australian motorist that it would reduce petrol prices in line with international oil prices, but it is prepared to let $2 billion flow into the country without wondering what its source is and whether there are any strings attached to it. Loan funds are supposed to be neutral. Banks make loans for debt without any strings attached. They are concerned only that the company is able to pay those loans back. But we know, it is a matter of public record, that there are strings attached to this loan. The Chartered Bank is not going to lend money to Holmes a Court unless he can give an assurance that he can get control of BHP. Why is the Chartered Bank concerned about Holmes a Court having control of BHP? I suggest that it could be for only one reason-there is a behind the scenes deal.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bank knows that, unless Holmes a Court can get control of BHP, he will not be in a position to sell off something, to increase the price of steel or to do whatever is necessary to balance his books. It has been shown in newspapers, particularly in the Age by Kenneth Davidson, that on the arithmetic of this bid the Bell Resources group will be $100m a year short with its cash flow. The money that the Bell Resources group will get from the shares it buys in BHP and the dividends from those shares will not cover the interest bill on the $2 billion; it will be short by $100m. So something has to give. Obviously there are all kinds of scenarios that one could paint as to how that $100m shortfall could be made up. He could increase the price of steel. He could sell off Utah to the Japanese. He could have a reverse take-over and have BHP take over Bell Resources. There are all sorts of things that he could do to balance his books. But we know, it is a matter of public record, that the money is lent to Bell Resources with strings attached, so it is not unreasonable for this Parliament and the Australian people to know what those strings are. How ironic it would be if, in a few months time, the Australian people, the Australian Government particularly and the Australian Labor Party generally, woke up to the fact that Holmes a Court had been a front for South African interests and that essentially BHP, the largest Australian owned company, was now owned and controlled by interests outside Australia. There has to be a public interest inquiry. I have received literally hundreds of letters from small shareholders in BHP. I read only one typical one. It is from Mrs Patrick Andersen. She writes:
I am a small shareholder in BHP. I have been listening to media reports about the proposed takeover bid by Mr Holmes a Court and have been very disturbed about what I heard.
Last night I saw your interview with Richard Carleton and for the first time I was pleased to hear sound judgment and commonsense at last, from anyone.

I had a dream for years to own some share in BHP to help in the growth of Australia. I saved enough a few years ago and bought 100 shares. I think the BHP board have been excellent and don't personally want that changed.

I am very distressed that Mr Holmes a Court can borrow $2 billion and we have to pay his interest. That is terribly wrong. Surely that big loophole in our laws has to be changed. Why should we have to pay when Mr Holmes a Court can afford his own interest debt.
The Liberal and Labor parties don't seem to be interested and I'm glad you are, and you also have the power to do something about it.
Please do.

Mr Holmes a Court is effectively a one-man band. He is borrowing $2 billion off-shore. He controls Bell Resources. He has a majority interest in that company through an intricate network of interchanging shares and options and so forth, but essentially that one man can control the voting power of the Bell Resources group and eventually that one man could also control the voting power of BHP if his bid succeeds. To put it in another perspective-and this is not original but I cite it for the record-it is the equivalent of one man controlling General Motors, IBM, General Electric and Rank-Xerox in the United States. Are we going to allow that sort of concentration of power in this country without a public inquiry and without knowing the source of the $2 billion? The Government is abrogating its public responsibility in suggesting that we should sit back and allow that to happen.

As far as the Democrats are concerned, much as we want this trade practices amendment legislation passed, we are going to vote against it-there is no shadow of a doubt about that-rather than see no public inquiry conducted. I understand that the Trade Practices Commission made a public statement at lunch time that, if section 50 (1A) remains, there will be a public inquiry. I quote that second hand; I hope I do not misquote him. This is a matter of overriding importance as the Democrats see it and it is the only, the fundamental, the sole reason why we are prepared, if necessary and if common sense is not going to prevail in this place, to block this important trade practices amendment legislation and reintroduce it as a private member's Bill without the offending proposed new sub-section 50 (2C).

We are debating whether we will delete 50 (2C). The simple thing would be for the Government to vote with the Democrats and delete 50 (2C). If the Government is not prepared to take the simple course, we seven Democrat senators have only one other course of action-to defeat the whole Bill and reintroduce it, without 50 (2C), as a private member's Bill. I cannot really believe that the Government is so perverse or pigheaded that it will not support our amendment to delete 50 (2C). Let us get on with the important business of the trade practices legislation. Let Holmes a Court, BHP, the shareholders and the Australian public know what is going to happen. The whole matter will then be in the hands of an official public inquiry. We will be able to have the official answers to these questions, and notably where the $2 billion is coming from, the question that Senator Gareth Evans was not prepared to answer when it was asked before lunch by Senator Don Chipp.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

It is very difficult to reply to him without appearing either to take sides, which the Government, of course, has been at the utmost pains not to do in this matter, or, more particularly, to reveal information we are simply not in a position to reveal at least at this stage. I can only repeat, and repeat with the utmost clarity, what I said this morning: The public interest issues in this matter, including every one of the kinds of issues that were raised by Senator Siddons, including even the South African connection, were raised in discussions with Mr Holmes a Court and, where relevant, with the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd as well, in the course of a very substantial and sustained discussion, supported by a quite substantial amount of written material then subsequently.
—Can you tell us with whom that three-hour discussion was held? If you cannot, I will accept that.
—With whom?
—Was it with the whole Cabinet?
—No, it was with the seven Ministers.
—The magnificent seven.

—The magnificent seven, as Senator McIntosh rightly says. The Ministers were Hawke, Keating, Evans, Button, Dawkins, Bowen and Willis. That is a matter of public record. It was a sustained discussion. All I can say is that we did receive certain assurances, though it was not in a courtroom situation, it was not under oath. In that sense one might argue that there are limitations in that kind of procedure, but in the case of the kinds of information and assurances we received from Mr Holmes a Court in particular and which led us to the conclusion that there was no public interest issue such as required or justified government intervention, on the information presently available the assurances which led us to reach those conclusions were such that I think the following can be said: Mr Holmes a Court's commercial credibility and certainly his credibility with this or any future government would be wrecked beyond repair if it proved to be the case that what he said to us orally and in writing was either inaccurate or in some way misleading.
—If he gets control of BHP, it ceases to matter.

—From someone with Senator Siddons's commercial experience, as one of the founding fathers of the Australian spanner, that is really a quite extraordinary assertion. Somebody's commercial reputation is absolutely of the essence if that person is to maintain credibility in the market-place, with all the financial institutions and the banks he deals with in any form of ongoing activity, unless one takes the extraordinary view that what Mr Holmes a Court is about is just a raid on BHP in order to strip its assets and then go into retirement thereafter, never to be seen again in any commercial or governmental environment.
—No, he will run the country instead.

—For someone who is supposed to be adopting an even-handed approach to this issue, as Senator Siddons indicated he was some little time ago, he is not putting a terribly effective face on it in his presentation of the argument. The point I am making is a very serious one. It is not a matter of legal capacity to commit someone for perjury or something of that kind. Obviously, that is not what is in issue here. It is a matter of credibility-credibility commercially and credibility with government.

SPEECH.PARA: I suppose that the Government has taken a risk by conducting an inquiry of this kind and bearing the burden of being proved later to be wrong. The justification for our being prepared to assume that risk lies in the point I have just made. We believe that those assurances are reliable. The information we have is reliable. It does go to the issues Senator Siddons addressed. Without being in a position to go into any more detail than that, I simply say, as the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said in his statement on behalf of the Cabinet, after it had endorsed the report of the seven Ministers, that there is no public interest issue such as justified intervention.

Under those circumstances, let us get back to the point in issue here, which is the justification or otherwise for the retention of this form of inquiry mode. The point here remains, as it has been throughout this debate, that whatever the justification may be in some circumstances for some kind of inquiry conducted by someone, the particular procedures, the particular ground rules, the particular criteria that are involved in a body like the Trade Practices Commission, with all the talent and expertise at its disposal and with the best will in the world, are just not appropriate. They are not the appropriate ground rules to be conducting an inquiry where what we have is a bare transfer of monopoly power.

The second of these amendments will have the effect of giving the Trade Practices Tribunal the power to conduct broad public interest inquiries into any takeover as it deems necessary. It will have the power to investigate an inquiry at its discretion. I believe that I have said enough today to make the Australian Democrats' position abundantly clear. We believe that there must be a tribunal in the land which can assess the public interest or detriment of any takeover, whether it is a takeover of a monopoly or not. It is common in most Western countries to have some safeguard to protect the public against detriment arising from takeovers, and that is all we are seeking to do.

Both the Australian Labor Party and the Opposition parties have made it very clear that they are not prepared to support section 50(1a). They want to neutralise the power of that section. So, it is very important that there be some tribunal in the land that can assess what is happening in takeovers of large public companies and whether this is in the public interest. Surely the case of the Holmes a Court takeover of the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd cannot be construed in any other way than as a matter involving the public interest.

Let us just look at the facts, and I will not take up much of the Senate's time. BHP employs 58,000 people. It pays $1.5 billion annually in salaries and wages. Last year BHP reinvested $880m into the business. It controls the steel industry and controls probably the largest reserves of high grade coking coal in the world. It controls Australia's oil industry, has significant interests in natural gas and controls the heavy engineering sector, and three towns-Whyalla, Wollongong and Newcastle-are totally dependent on that company.

Steel is a basic raw material and its price affects most of the other metal industries in this country. BHP has a monopoly position which could easily be abused by an unscrupulous board of directors simply by raising the price ahead of the consumer price index. Steel is strategically vitally important to this country, as are oil and coal. For these reasons there is a very vital public interest. The Government has already put $50m a year over the past two years into the steel division of BHP and it intends to put in another $50m. How could anyone say that BHP, its ownership and the way in which it is controlled, whether by one man or by a responsible board of directors, is not a matter involving the public interest? Of course the public has a very considerable interest, to say nothing of the 180,000 shareholders who also want to make sure that they are not being outmanoeuvred by large shareholders in BHP with pro rata bids, partial bids or whatever. If, as the Government wishes, section 50(1a) is neutralised, there is no tribunal in the land that can look into any aspect of a takeover. It is absolutely free and open slather for market forces.

I conclude by saying this: We now have in this country a situation where both the major political parties refuse to confront major matters of national importance. Both parties are breaking their necks to hand over as much of the economic power of this country as they can to foreign interests. Both parties use free market arguments to enable governments to renege on their responsibilities to the Australian people to manage the economy in such a way that the interests of the community are safeguarded. The electors of this country are being sold down the river and this enrages and sickens me.

SPEECH.PARA: One could have some degree of sympathy if the actual proposals contained in proposed section 50aa were in understandable terminology. I am curious in that sense alone to know what is the difference between the public interest and the national interest. I certainly do not understand that.

One would be slightly more sanguine if in fact the existing public benefit test had really amounted to anything in the past. ` . . . the interests of the public as purchasers, consumers or users . . . fall within it-

and bulk large'.

To that extent I do not think that there is anything reliable or concrete that can be adduced to demonstrate what would be the effect. What I am suspicious of is erecting a regime which would have some parallels with the operations of the United Kingdom Monopolies and Mergers Commission which has, I think, on the initiative of the British Government been used on occasions not so much in the `public benefit' or the `national interest' but in the particular interests of the government of the day.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that what you think the John Elliott one was?

—Senator Haines rightly raises the John Elliott situation. The Elders IXL take-over appears now to be a failed takeover, a thwarted takeover or a postponed takeover. —Is it not a matter of terms of reference? Will not the criteria for the inquiry determine whether government policy or the public interest or, more importantly, public detriment were taken into account?

—If in fact there were criteria which were objectively laid down within the body of the Act, that might indeed be a point worth considering. It seems to me that the whole thrust of the amendments which have been proposed are, to a very large extent, designed to have the effect of freeing the operation of the market and of allowing shareholders to make a determination as to whether a takeover bid should or should not succeed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make one suggestion. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think Senator Siddons's latest enterprise is a trifle disingenuous. The Government will oppose this amendment on a number of grounds, most of which have already in fact been canvassed by Senator Puplick in his contribution to this debate. I am happy on this occasion to have left some of the pedantries to some other senator in this chamber rather than being responsible for all of it myself.
—Actually I prefer being insulted by you rather than flattered.

—I will do my best to oblige Senator Puplick in the future. What Senator Siddons's proposal seeks to do of course is to subject all takeovers, but not mergers, falling outside the takeover code to possible blocking action by reference to the Trade Practices Commission on the initiative, not just as is presently is the case where neither the Trade Practices Commission nor the Minister may initiate such action, but any other person can in fact do so on Senator Siddons's model.

SPEECH.PARA: The Tribunal accordingly is then given a very largely unfettered discretion to declare that takeover contrary to the national interest. It can have regard to a variety of criteria not necessarily tied in any way to competition effects; not necessarily tied, that is, to the kinds of things the Trade Practices Act and the Trade Practices Commission are all about.

It may or may not be a good thing as a matter of public policy to have some sort of mechanism available to deal with certain takeovers which do not necessarily infringe on competition policy guidelines. There is quite a lively argument as to whether the particular machinery, for example which is available in the United Kingdom with the Monopolies and Mergers Commission, the Office of Fair Trading and so on, has been a useful instrument of public policy in the protection of the public interest in that country. There are arguments on both sides of that. There is an argument that might usefully be held, I guess, at some stage in this country. However, the particular proposal which Senator Siddons has come up with is not one that even with a degree of loving care and attention in a committee for a week or so could I breathe back any kind of life into it because the basic concept behind Senator Siddons's amendment is one that is just full of holes.

The difficulty to start with-really this is the central problem-is that takeovers would be automatically stayed by a reference to the Commission. Given the capacity of anyone at all to initiate this proceeding any person could block any takeover for an indefinite period while an inquiry was held into the national interest-a question itself which obviously is an indefinite one and difficult to define.

What this would allow is virtually untrammelled intervention into the takeover process, not by government armed with some very keen perception of what the national or public interest might be in a particular case, which is the situation in Britain, where the Government plays the crucial role in determining whether these sorts of blocking manoeuvres take effect either temporarily or permanently, but by anyone at all. There would, as a result, be enormous uncertainty. We really would cut a swath through takeover activity in this country. It would be a paradise for takeover defenders, which may in some instances be appropriate in the public interest, but hardly as a general state of affairs, where takeovers must be regarded as one of the ordinary incidents of the capitalist system and one that make it, for better or worse-whatever one's basic ideological position is-work better.

Certainly, this Government has no desire whatsoever to remove from the present business system those elements in its dynamics which do make it work effectively and well within its own criteria. What we then have as part of the Siddons model is a conferring on the Tribunal of a wide open discretion to block particular take- overs-after all the sterilisation of the takeover had taken place-and to do so in a way that does not leave any final decision with government, which is again essentially the British model, but rather leaves the decision with the Tribunal itself, subject only to some appeal on the merits to the Federal Court or a State Supreme Court.

The proposal as a whole is not one which I understand has met with any enthusiasm at all from the Law Council of Australia, which in other respects has been something of a guiding light to the Australian Democrats' front bench, if not to its back bench. I just mention that not out of any spirit of scoring a quick debating point, but simply to indicate that to those who would have to make this particular proposal work, it just is not a goer.

There are three technical points I also want to quickly make, and which no doubt I suppose could be remedied but not without some damage being caused to the concepts which lie behind this particular model. In the first place, the amendment, by referring to bodies corporate in general terms, without confining it to the categories of corporation identified in the Constitution, is to that extent unconstitutional and runs beyond constitutional bounds. As I say, that is remedial but it indicates the rather quick way in which this draft has obviously been put together and the fact that it is unacceptable in its present form.

A much more substantial problem with the present draft, again a technical constitutional problem, is that it provides in proposed sub-section (10) for an appeal to a court from the Tribunal on the merits. But we cannot have in our system an appeal from a tribunal to a court on the merits. The Constitution provides that judicial power can be exercised by courts and non-judicial power can be exercised by non-courts, and never the twain shall meet. While we can have a review procedure from tribunals to the courts to ensure that the tribunals have behaved properly according to the rules of natural justice, or whatever, and have used fair decision-making procedures we cannot have a review on the merits. That point has not been fully appreciated by the drafter of this and there are basic flaws with this particular model as a result.

There is a further problem with proposed section 50AA sub-section (5), which would modify the Companies (Acquisition of Shares) Act and thereby would be in breach of the Commonwealth-State formal agreement-clause 47 (1) of it for the enthusiasts among us-unless it was first agreed to by the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities. So quite apart from anything else, we could not enact that particular part of the model. Again, sub-section 50AA (4) may also modify the Companies (Acquisition of Shares) Act and thereby be in breach of the formal agreement in that from 31 March the offeror must get the consent of the NCSC to withdraw an offer. That follows by virtue of section 21 of the agreement. So for a variety of reasons of high principle, practicality and legal pedantry, the Government resists the Siddons amendment and urges the Committee to vote accordingly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition is opposed to Senator Siddons's amendment which proposes to insert into the Trade Practices Act a new section to provide for wide-ranging inquiries in regard to all takeover offers. The Opposition is opposed to it not for any technical reasons which may or may not be able to be fixed up by a committee consideration of it-Senator Gareth Evans has already made mention of this-but we are opposed to it quite firmly on philosophic grounds. This amendment clearly defines the very great gulf there is between their attitude to takeovers and that of the Opposition. Fortunately, it seems to be a view which the Government, or the majority of the Government, shares with the Opposition. We already have had a debate in the Senate on a motion by Senator Siddons expressing his and the Democrats' attitude to takeovers. We have had a great deal of public comment on takeovers from the Democrats over the last few weeks since this became the subject of major debate. It is quite clear that the Democrats' attitude is one which is highly interventionist, highly regulatory. The Democrats want to have the Government, or some agency of the Government, deeply involved as a monitor and controller of takeover activity.

SPEECH.PARA: This proposal by Senator Siddons goes far beyond anything which we have been debating or which has been debated in the public arena about the BHP takeover. This amendment, it must be remembered, is not another form or extension of the problem with takeovers of monopolies that section 50 (1) and section 50 (2C) have addressed. This proposal refers to all takeovers: `constitutes a takeover offer', the amendment reads. In no way is it confined to the problem we have been debating today and which has been debated in recent days in the public arena about takeovers of monopolies. The difference between the Australian Democrats and us on this is a very deep one indeed.

There is no way in which we, on principle, in a discussion with the Democrats would be able to come to some agreement on this sort of proposal. Not only does it apply to all takeovers; as Senator Puplick has already pointed out, it applies criteria which are enormously wide, apart from being enormously vague. So the inquiry would be of the most wide-ranging kind in relation to both takeovers and the considerations that are to be taken into account by the body that is looking into takeovers. Then, of course, that body finally would have this very great power to stop such a takeover taking effect. Leaving aside the question of whether it is possible to do so or not-there is an appeal process-the fact is that this body would be given these enormous powers not only over what are ordinary and common commercial activities and arrangements but also over what, in the Opposition's view, in most cases are very valu- able activities.

I am very pleased to see that Senator Evans and the Government seem to have a so much better appreciation of the capitalist economy than they used to have. It goes to the very heart of making the system work. There can be exceptions to any rule, but by and large the likelihood of takeovers, and in many cases the exercise of the right of takeover, proves highly beneficial. Therefore, we could not be a party to any proposals to control takeover activities which would inhibit the whole process to the extent that the Democrats obviously wish. At least we must be grateful that in this amendment the Democrats are giving full expression to their views about takeover activity.

Even if there could be advanced a case for a means of investigating a takeover of a monopoly, our view is as we have just expressed it-by a vote here we have given clear affirmation of it-that is, that the powers which presently are in the Trade Practices Act to investigate a takeover of a monopoly are not appropriate. That would be our view even if a different proposal which may have greater commendation could be advanced. However, we are not faced with that. The Government has not put forward such a proposal and the Opposition has not fully investigated it at this point either. No doubt it is something that a lot of people will be thinking about in the light of this experience. Even if there were some other way of approaching this question, in the Opposition's view it certainly would not be of the kind that the Democrats are suggesting in this amendment. As I said, for very deep and strong philosophic reasons and because of the very good and strong arguments that can be advanced in favour of improving and maintaining the present economic system or capitalist system-whatever you like to call it-the Opposition simply could not support the sort of approach that is embodied in Senator Siddons's amendments.

Although I was rather amused to hear the suggestion that we and the Democrats might be able to get together-in fact, in a committee-in view of the Democrats' strong vote against the Opposition's proposal to refer the whole of this Bill to a committee, on behalf of the Opposition I can assure Senator Siddons that we certainly do not see any likelihood of being able to reach agreement on this sort of proposal. We will vote against it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Durack for at least making the Opposition's position clear; that there is, as he said, a wide gulf of principle or philosophy separating the Democrats and the Opposition in the initiative this amendment represents. I reiterate that we are being governed at the moment by a parliament which has both the Government and the Opposition in absolute agreement on economic management; that is, hands off the economy, no government interference, let the market forces rule. That is commonly called the dry approach. We have a government which if it were any drier would spontaneously combust, supported by an opposition. It is a tragedy for the country. I say no more.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 19 September 1985 (Hansard, page 749), Senator Harradine asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Health, a question without notice concerning hospital day care benefits. The Minister for Health has provided the following information:

ANSWER.PARA: The basic aim of the hospital day care legislation, which came into effect as from 1 September 1985, was to rationalize and co-ordinate payments of fund hospital benefits for private hospital patients and payments of the Commonwealth daily bed subsidy.

Before 1 September 1985, patients had to be in a private hospital for at least 8 hours for the hospital to attract a Commonwealth daily bed subsidy of $20, $30 or $40, depending on the category of hospital. Fund benefits were not necessarily restricted by this ``8 hour rule''-they were paid or not paid according to individual funds' rules. However, most funds would have paid full inpatient benefits for under 8 hour stays.

As from 1 September 1985, the Commonwealth daily bed subsidy is not payable for non-overnight stays. A new fund benefit of $80 is payable from the basic table for day only care. Theatre fee benefits are payable from supplementary tables for day only care.

The new day care benefit is designed to encourage day care, with its concomitant advantages in terms of financial savings to the community and convenience for patients. The new benefit was introduced only after consultation with the AMA, the private hospital and insurance industries, and the States.

Research has shown that there are substantial savings to hospitals in providing day only care. These savings flow from the less serious nature of the procedures provided and the less intensive nursing and support care provided, as well as the cost savings associated with non-overnight stays.

Under the pre 1 September arrangements, some hospitals were charging full inpatient fees, plus theatre fees, for day only patients receiving relatively minor procedures. The Government believes that it is reasonable to expect that hospitals realise that their fees should be reasonably aligned with costs.
The new day care benefit was set at a level which research showed would cover the cost incurred by an efficient organisation in providing day care surgery (when theatre fee benefits were included).

It is important to note that the day care benefit of $80 (plus theatre fee benefit if appropriate) was designed to cover the average cost of providing such care. Thus, the benefit takes into account the fact that costs associated with some procedures would be less than $80, whereas in other cases they may be higher. In framing the legislation, it was considered that one level of benefit covering all procedures would be administratively simpler for hospitals and health benefits organisations than having a separate benefit for each procedure.

Therefore, provided that hospitals structure their fees (including theatre fees) so that they bear a reasonable relationship to average costs associated with day care procedures, insured patients should not need to make a significant personal contribution. Likewise, where a patient dies on the same day that he or she is admitted, the cost to the hospital should not, on average, vary significantly from that for persons admitted as day care patients.

It is up to individual hospitals to determine their own admission policies. It is to be hoped, however, that the needs of the patient would be of paramount importance. As discussed above, research has shown that there are substantial savings to hospitals in providing day only care. In the circumstances, in respect of a patient requiring only day care services, there would appear to be little justification for a hospital adopting such practices as discharging patients after midnight or admitting them the evening before the relevant procedures are planned to take place.

I would like to emphasise to the honourable senator that it is up to hospitals to align their charges reasonably with the costs they incur. The ``hardships'' referred to in the honourable senator's question may in fact flow from a desire on the part of some private hospitals to maintain their past unrealistic and inflated profit levels from day only patients.
The community cannot afford to continue to squander scarce financial resources in this way.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Science, upon notice, on 19 February 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What plans are in place or projected for early warning systems to aid Bureau of Meteorology Scientists and Forecasters with their cyclone and storm forecasts, in view of the devastation caused on the North Queens- land coast by cyclone `Winifred' on the weekend of February 1 and 2 1986, and the constant threat to Queensland and Western Australia of loss of life, injury and property damage during cyclone seasons.
(2) What level of equipment will be required, and at what estimated cost.
(3) Can the Minister for Science indicate when a satisfactory system of precyclone warning will be available to scientists and forecasters.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Science has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Proposals are being prepared, for consideration in the Budget context, to substantially upgrade the Bureau of Meteorology's warning system for severe weather, including tropical cyclones, and to increase capital funding to replace obsolete equipment and introduce new technology.
The Bureau's high priority capital projects include initiatives in the following areas:
- the upgrading of satellite acquisition and processing facilities;
- the improvement of the weather watch radar network;
- the installation of computers in Regional Offices; and
- the installation of specialised mesoscale networks of automatic weather stations.

In 1986/87 the Bureau of Meteorology is to undertake a major research project, the Australian Monsoon Experiment (AMEX), aimed in particular at improving understanding of the Australian summer monsoon. The results of AMEX will add greatly to knowledge of the tropical atmosphere and tropical cyclone genesis.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 12 February 1986 (Hansard, page 176) Senator Watson asked me as Minister representing the Minister for Science a question, without notice, about forecasting and warning services in the Bureau of Meteorology. The Minister for Science has provided the following additional information in response to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The Bureau of Meteorology already has programs underway aimed at making more effective use of its resources through the utilisation of recent scientific and technical developments. In addition, proposals have been prepared, for consideration in the Budget context, to upgrade the warning system for severe weather and to increase capital funding for the introduction of new technology and replacement of obsolete equipment.

The reference to comments attributed to Mr Arch Shields, a former Regional Director of the Bureau of Meteorology in Queensland, presumably refers to an interview published in The Australian of 10 February 1986.

It is true that the Bureau cooperative observer network was run down in the 1970s from a peak of approximately 570 stations to approximately 430 due to constraints on the Bureau during that period. It is also true that the Hawke Government is taking steps to improve the observing network. For example, a new Bureau-staffed station equipped with radar was opened recently at Gove and a radar is planned for installation at Weipa this year.

The Bureau is attempting to use available resources to maximise the benefits of the observing network, and the technical infrastructure, including satellites, computers and automatic weather stations. The latter are complementary to the land based observing networks and play a vital role in the modern tropical cyclone warning system.

Regular satellite pictures provide the broad surveillance of the atmosphere necessary for the detection of tropical storms over the oceans. Without satellite surveillance the warning lead time for coastal communities would be considerably reduced. Interpretation of satellite data also allows very good estimation of the intensity of tropical cyclones.

Computers in the Tropical Cyclone Warning Centres are necessary to speed up a variety of data processing tasks, most importantly the preparation and dissemination of warning messages to responsible authorities and the media. During the recent tropical cyclone Winifred, up to 100 addresses were notified of each warning by the Brisbane office.

Automatic weather stations (AWS) are essential to provide basic data where it is not practicable to use trained observers. AWS give regular reports from coral reef atolls and islands and they are able to provide regular reports overnight when it it difficult to arrange for cooperative observers. It is true that early model AWS did have reliability problems but modern instruments have been developed to a higher standard.

Notwithstanding the above, the Bureau recognises that the networks of observing stations staffed by trained observers and cooperative observers are still vital components of the forecasting and warning system. These networks provide detailed observations of a type not available from satellite data. The Bureau has recently announced a plan to boost training of observers.
The investment and distribution of resources between staff and equipment has to be viewed in the context of the Bureau's integrated operational program and not as a series of discrete activities.

During the five week period to 14 February 1986 the rider `meteorologists warn that this forecast is based on inadequate information' was appended to 202 forecasts and warnings issued by the Bureau. During the same period more than 50,000 separate forecasts and warnings were issued. Although the rider has been used on a relatively small percentage of occasions the Government is, of course, concerned.

The initiative referred to earlier (the proposed upgrade of the warning systems and capital equipment funding, the increased training of observers) will make a significant contribution to the amount and quality of data available to meteorologists. These initiatives will improve the quality of forecast and warning services and thereby further reduce the occasions when meteorologists might consider it appropriate to append a rider to the forecast or warning.
